reviewText:
WHAT IS IT?

Its a story driven visual anime novel. Most of the game is text supported by frozen snapshots showing mostly girls in uniform. The story itself is massive but shallow regarding plot and excution. Gameplay distributes into a)reading b)selecting a path c)unit progress d)combat

a) reading (story)
Let me say that my younger self (a former anime geek) would ve been absolutely THRILLED if this would have been available in my time. It has everything a young male teenager would want.....girls, mecha, me being the hero, nudity, big boobs. Several decades later my mature self remembers how this feels but I cannot ignore the holes and unrealistic behaviour as well as technological improbabilities. Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius is nothing more then a fairy tale in space. How any of the main characters would end up in their positions (captain, commander, fighter pilots) keeping the childish views and behaviour is beyond me....still....its amusing if only for its nostalgic value and I cannot help but wonder if the hero will get" the girl :) It took me about 2 days to play through and even tho I would rate this "book" a 4/10 it was entertaining and easy to read...nothing to wrap your head around but then....its free so theres nothing to complain about really.

b) selecting a path
The first couple hours start promising. After the tutorial mission you are presented with a galaxy chart offering different systems you can visit. Many places dont open up before you talk to various crewmembers. Theres a hint of side-missions which would enable farming and a distraction but in reality the available content is extremely limited and becomes non-existant after a few hours when all you do is to follow the main story. All in all the game "tries" to present multiple paths but in reality its as linear as it can get.

c) unit progress
You start out with your flagship and collect Ryders (mecha) throughout the story. Each unit is represented with its own arsenal and abilities (support
hoursPlayed:
anti-mecha) and statistics providing numerical values in combat. Kills in combat provide a bounty which goes into your treasury as well as command points which are pooled for extra actions during battle. You improve unit stats by allocating funds to certain areas with each improvement becoming more expensive. This system gives you the opportunity to "specilaize" your units but money is extremely tight with no means to generate "extra" income (like repeating missions or an "open" environment which enables you to farm) you are dependant on getting optimal results in battles (re-playing them until you get it right) and a good "build" (dont waste money on upgrades you dont really need). Enemy units also become more powerfull and battles are always stacked against you. This can be extremely frustrating and forced me to take breaks in between to regenerate my motivation.

d) combat
Turn-based
voteText: hexagonal battle map with 2-shot battle animations. The combat system WANTS to look intimidating and complex but it fails as strengths and weaknesses are obvious and easy to exploit. Defensive play tops offensive in almost every skirmish and important command decisions are out of your hand as they are woven into the story so you are left with mop-ups or survival scenarios while the critical things (warp out of harms way
helpfulPercent: fire a torpedo down the death stars chute.......errrrr....I mean fire your main cannon directily into the enemies flagship planet destroyer nozzle) are displayed in text form. Combat eventually becomes repetitive
votesHelpful:
boring and also annoying where I find myself wanting to be done with it in order to continue the story.



Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius is advertised as an anime novel and thats what it is. Gameplay is extremely limited as everything centers around the story which takes you by the hand and forces you into a "tunnel" to avoid any problems and distractions. I found myself flipping through the pages (clicking space) and reading the dialoges only to groan in annoyance whenever a combat came up. All you do really is click through available NPCs (order doesnt matter much) in order to relive memories and see how the story evolves. As far as I can see there is ZERO replay-value without multiple endings and maybe 2 or 3 side missions in the whole "game".


Now this might read like a crushing review but to be honest....its not that bad :)

First of all its FREE so what do you lose except time? The story itself is typical anime with a single male hero surrounded by young girls of various character (shy

The universe is threatened by an "evil" opponent and you represent the only force of "good" with forces around you which you are unsure about (is the Alliance a force of good or out after after their own goals?). Mecha-design and exotic weapons appeal to the inner geek and the scarcly clad anime girls (young

reviewText:
So it's a visual novel/turn based battle thing. Basically a sort-of X-Com with anime girls. Huh.

I had serious misgivings about installing this one, even though it was a free game. First impressions made it look like the sort of bad waifu VN I would feel ashamed playing, but it was a free game with high reviews. At least if it sucked I wouldn't have had to spend any money. So I decided to try it.

Turns out... it's actually quite good.

Yes it does have a number of immature anime things, and even playing the regular (censored) version of this there were more than a few suggestive moments and some very brief nudity. And yet all of this is set against a rather dark and serious backdrop: galactic warfare and all the horrible things that come with that. It gets particularly psychological and tense later on as your character ends up with nightmares about stuff that happens in the plot that comes back to haunt him in a PTSD sort of way. I'm not going to say more than that because spoilers, but all you really need to know is that the story kept me interested. And, during several moments, coming away fairly impressed by what these indie devs had done.

In short... don't judge this by its cover. There is much more here than a bunch of silly anime girls.

As for the characters, it's pretty good with a few bad eggs. It's pretty much a full roster of all the anime girl archetypes you can think of: the overserious workaholic (Ava), the genki girl (Asaga), the shy genius (Chigara), the tsundere (Icari), the massive pervert (Claude), the kuudere/Rei clone (Sola), and the trusty idealistic soldier (Kryska). But all of them stand out in their own ways, even if not all of those ways are positive (Claude is basically a pervert fanservice doctor and nothing else). There is a sizeable male cast, believe it or not, and some of them are actually interesting (Admiral Grey, Fontana) even if others (Arcadius) just seem like stereotypes.

Gameplay makes this a mix of VN decision-making (some of which are rather difficult and made me take some time to think about), tactical battles, and some management stuff as you upgrade equipment or do side-missions. The battles can be tough, sometimes absurdly so, but there's nothing technically wrong with them. There was one moment that annoyed me a bit concerning a story mission where I knew exactly what the enemy was planning, and yet I was not able to act on that knowledge because the story needed to convince me that this particular enemy was smart or something when, if this had been a strategy game, I would have torn him apart. At least the hair-raising scene after that battle (Let me show you war") was worth it
date: and led to probably my most morally questionable decision I made in my playthrough.\n\nTruthfully I found myself more interested in the story than the battles
recommended: and kinda wished I could skip them a few times because other things were going on that I was more interested in. At least in Key/Visual Arts' VN Little Busters! you got an option to skip the Baseball and Battle Ranking minigames if you wanted (but why would you? The Battle Ranking stuff was great! XD).\n\nAt time of writing
hoursPlayed: this game isn't finished. There's still more story being written so I can't really make an absolute recommendation on this because of that. But based on what I have seen so far
voteText: this game has real promise. :D"

reviewText:
Sunrider: First Arrival is a Visual Novel style RPG Tactics, it is a science fiction type of game. Well, if you think this is just another of those lousy and cheesy anime game. You are wrong. Believe me, you are wrong. This is a tactics game, if you ever play Final Fantasy Tactics or Agarest: Generation of War, it is that type of game.

The gameplay mechanic is very fun i might say, you can upgrade your ship or your mecha crew, like you want to make it stronger, or deals much more damage. The thing that you can upgrade is a lot. The battle mechanic is simple but fun, basically you got multiple skill and type of attack, like long range beam attack, gun attack, laser attack, rocket, and you need to use the right type of attack at the right type of the enemy, if for example you are facing the cruiser with alot of armor, you cannot just use the gun attack because the gun attack deal less damage against the enemy with alot of armor, or if your enemy is a light mecha, you can't use a long range beam attack against them since they be able to dodge it easily.

Outside of the combat, you got some Mass Effect ish kinda interaction in your ship, you talked to your crew try to get to know them. The story is very good, i might say it is like Mass Effect in the way that there's some choice that seems right, but when you choose it some innocent people die because of it. The Lore is deep also, i don't think there's good or bad here, It just politics.

Soo, well its free. From the quality alone this game is very good that is on par with the game that cost 15 dollars. But it is free. Recommended to the highest level !!

reviewText:
Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius is a completely FREE visual novel and a strategy game. There's no catch. You just download it and you can play the entire game for free.

The story and gameplay are surprisingly good for a free game.

There are several difficulty modes. I recommend playing on the default one; it's challenging, but not impossible. There are harder modes if you're looking for a challenge and easier modes if just want to experience the story. Don't be afraid to challenge yourself because you can change the difficulty at anytime (even in the middle of a battle).

Honestly, I'd pay $5-10 for this game, but luckily it's FREE, so what are you waiting for?

reviewText:
Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius is one of those games where you can definitely feel the love and care that went into its creation. The game's studio, Love In Space, have worked on a few titles all revolving around the same universe (same people different situation) but this is my first taste of their work. I have not finished the game but I can say I am very impressed.

The game is similiar to other hexagonal grid turn-based RPGs but with a visual novel twist. It's not quite a dating simulator and not quite a choose your own adventure".

You play as Kayto Shields
date: recently promoted to command of your very own advanced warship named the Sunrider. The galaxy finds itself at war with the evil space communists and it's up to you
hoursPlayed: to stop their evil plans! ok
voteText:
so the plot is a lot more complex than that but to avoid spoilers I'll just leave it at that.

The game handles combat in a fairly traditional way. It's not a technical marvel by any stretch of the imagination with effects simply being layered over the image onscreen. What it lacks in flashiness it makes up for in character....characters.... The game takes your standard grid combat system and has you spend action points to move and shoot your enemies to oblivion with certain units having special attack and support abilities. The heart of your strength is the Sunrider itself but you also get a fleet of space mechs that you deploy at the start of every combat into whatever formation you desire. This is where the previously mentioned "character(s)" comes into play.

On your journey you manage to build up what many familiar with anime and dating sims will immediately recognize as your "space harem". These lovely ladies accompany you on your journey and lend their aid as fighters
helpfulPercent: medics
votesHelpful: support craft
votesTotal: etc
votesFunny: and greatly benefit you when it comes to dealing out the whoopass. Thier personalities range from shy
commentsCount: goofy
column16: stoic
column17: serious
column18: etc. Now while this is probably sounding a lot like a dating sim with some combat sprinkled in I will report
column19: to either your delight or annoyance
column20:
that this game does not turn into one big tail chase. There are romances that develope over the course of the story but everything plays forth in a fairly straightforward manner. You do encounter several big decisions to make in your travels but since I have only gone through certain choices I cannot say if they redically alter the story or the crew's feelings for you.

After combat you receive funds based on the enemies destyroyed and how much damage you have taken. You then spend this currency at your R&R depertment upgrading shields and weapons. You can also stock up on special components and powerful limited-use weapons from a special shop. Overall the system works really well and you really feel a sense of progression as you see your meager fighting force become something to think twice about. Not that the enemy is going to do much second guessing as some stages turn brutal really fast. One moment you're mopping up the floor with enemy fighters and the next they're warping in space carriers and battleships. These guys don't mess around either. Positioning is everything and enemies can quickly overwhelm you. Multiple saves are a must as one bad decision can lead to death fast. Thankfully the game features multiple difficulty levels and you can even play on a mode so easy you just have to go through the motions and victory is assured.

The amount of work that went into this game shows and like I mentioned earlier this really is a labor of love. The game features an opening straight out of a game from Japan (with authentic Japanese vocals from an eroge singer) and very pleasant artwork. The characters are fully voiced during combat and this is really where the character shines through. While the voice acting is decent the lines the characters say during a fight are really charming and reflect the personality types well. Want to hear a quirky anime girl shout
column21:
"Imma firing my lazers!!!"? Play Sunrider.

I really have to mention the soundtrack which is very well done. It fits the tone of the game very well and even after multiple battles I still have yet to tire of it. The music that plays when you issue your super laser command especially gets my blood pumping.

To wrap this review up I have to mention the price. If you havne't noticed already the game is FREE. FREEEEE. You really don't even need to read this review. If you think it looks cool from the images and the description sounds cool then download it. The game loads super fast and is easy to pick up and play.

Before I end I will mention this game is only PART 1. The next part is releasing soon (as far as I know. Check their website) and should be available on Steam. It sounds like you will have to pay for the next game but this first part alone is about 20 hours of gameplay alone so have fun! I enjoyed it so much I downloaded their full-on dating sim spinoff game Sunrider Academy. Definitely a recomendation if you like the characters and want to see them all in a HS setting......and naked......if you're into that sort of thing. Both games have a restoration patch from the Love In Space website to restore censored content (not sure what was cut from Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius since it's pretty tame so far)."

reviewText:
My review for Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius (or Sunrider only, because Mask of Arcadius is the second episode of the game, and the first one, First Arrival, also included in this game)

So, let's get started.

Sunrider:

- Free (most important in my opinion)

- Turn-based strategy RPG battle, build your own space fleet with their various upgrades.

- Various difficulties, more challenge.

- Developer Console for the people who's here for the story only.

As for the Visual Novel

- Nice story, Like watching good movies or reading good stories, Sunrider impress me well.

- Various character, with their unique traits, and different background which makes the story more understandable and entertaining.

- The CGs (the visual illustration) are well done, beautiful, and with the good story, makes a great combination.

- Tailored stories, you choose your own path, and some aspect on the story might be different based on your choices.

8.8/10

The game is actually divided into episodes, like what Telltale games did to their games (The Walking Dead, Wolf Among Us, and Game of Thrones), I only tried The Walking Dead, and one episodes of Sunrider is more or less same like one episode in The Walking Dead. The good thing is the first two episodes of Sunrider is completely free, I don't know about the next episodes, though. By the time I wrote this review, Sunrider still on the 2nd episode.

Honestly I'm here only for the story, which is good. And I think next episodes there will be Dating Sim feature. If it's true then I'm looking forward to that.

reviewText:
I normally would have stayed away from a game like this (judging books by there covers and all that), but i noticed it was free. And when i say free, completely free. You get the entire game, there is no in game store or micro transactions. They were funded on kickstarter, and are not even going to charge for the game. So with that being said, i gave the game a try. And Im sure glad i did. Its a great visual novel (my first actually) mixed with some great turn based strategy. A wide range of customizations are available for your ryders so you can tune them to how you want to play. The funniest moments Ive had in a video game come from the encounters you have with your crew. I havent finished the game yet (8.3 hours), but so far have really enjoyed it. Im probably gonna go throw some money at the devs because i have some triple A games that i havent enjoyed this much.
And to be that guy...

reviewText:
Short review:

Fantastic game. If you've ever been a fan of either tactical strategy games or visual novels, Sunrider is for you.


Full review:

As a long time fan of both visual novels and strategy games, I found Sunrider to contain the best elements of both.

The strategic fleet management system eschews traditional RPG leveling up" in favor of cash-based upgrades for your ships that can be partially refunded and reallocated. All of your potential to create success in the missions begins with how you spend your cash
date: so spend wisely and plan your upgrades around what you want your team to accomplish.\n\nOnce you enter the fray
recommended: you'll find a tactical battle system that is
hoursPlayed: in a word
voteText: challenging. At normal (or "Captain") difficulty
helpfulPercent: even as a 25 year veteran of strategic and tactical gaming
votesHelpful: there were several missions that had me pulling my hair out as my comrades were annihilated one after another by the unrelenting tide of foes. But that made the satisfaction of eventually conquering those missions all the higher
votesTotal: and if you want a more casual experience or are only playing for the story
votesFunny: don't let the battles frighten you. Many easier levels of difficulty are available
commentsCount: including one that makes the battles a mere formality so that you can get on with the story.\n\nAnd you'll want to get on with the story
column16: as it is surprisingly deep and exists in a beautiful area of moral uncertainty that few games tackle as successfully. There are choices to make that will leave you feeling like Sunrider isn't just a game; in a game
column17: the hero should always be able to do the obvious right things
column18: save every princess
column19: and slay every dragon. But in Sunrider
column20: you may have to choose between the princess and the kingdom
column21: knowing you can never rescue both. You may even be surprised to realize that the dragon isn't necessarily the villain. In that sense
column22: Sunrider recalls the best moments of morally ambiguous visual novels like G-Senjou no Maou. It will make you question the nature of good and evil.\n\nThe obviously limited budget and tiny development crew would be easy to cite as drawbacks
column23: but in my view they benefit Sunrider enormously. I can imagine many ways that throwing better graphics or higher production values at the game would just detract from its tactical and storytelling heart. The simple anime-style artwork serves its purpose and effectively connects the player to the mostly-likeable characters. If there's anything negative to say
column24: it would be that the voice work of the combat lines doesn't add much to the game given the high amounts of repetition. I would have instead preferred to see voicework in the actual dialogue segments between fights.\n\nIt comes down to this: If you have ever had space in your heart (no pun intended) for story driven tactical strategy
column25: play this game. You won't be disappointed
column26: and it will cost you nothing but a little of your time.\n\nOr a lot of your time."

reviewText:
For a free game, it's nice. I was impressed with the quality of the music and sounds. The art is crisper than it appears in the videos, but I was still a bit disappointed in the minimal animation. The game is story driven so you will find yourself clicking through a lot of exposition between stages. The story doesn't do it for me personally but some might enjoy it more.. far it seems pretty linear, we'll see how much they let your choices affect dispositions/outcomes by the end. The strategy is not incredibly complex but provides some casual fun with a fair amount of choices via upgrades system. There are three levels of difficulty though I don't know how they scale yet. Unfortunately it's a purely single player experience, but definitely worth a play.

One big gripe I have is that I wish they would change is to make the unit-select work by clicking on the whole tile rather than the unit outlines. It's very easy to misclick and it makes the interface feel sticky. The deck select seems needlessly complex as well-- Same with cutscenes for every attack, although I do appreciate that you can click through them.

reviewText:
I'm no stranger to Visual Novels or gaming in general, and while Sunrider probably isn't going to epitomize any element of its genre, it's a solid fun game worth the play at $20, never mind free.

The Plot
The plot is fairly straightforward, and a lot of tropes are played straight. To the best of my knowledge, no choice can lead you to a failure state (save through choices made in the combat layer); instead, choices decide what kind of a captain you want to be, and to act contrary to built-up ideals at some critical points is harder than to continue to play your beliefs straight (represented by the offering of the other option at a small cost of in-game command points).

The writing and dialogue isn't really award worthy, but it's certainly playable. I'd even call it better than average for a VN, and the occasional moments where things really come together more than make up for any bland parts.

The Gameplay
The real meat of the game is its combat. Battles are challenging and rewarding at Captain, one of the six difficulty levels, and different tactical approaches offer different levels of risk and reward on scales from the immediate to the long-term. Much of this is accomplished through the surprisingly deep upgrade system. While there aren't any trees to climb or alternate ships to swap your pilots into, there's plenty of stats to focus on and their synergies can stretch beyond the immediately apparent. Play well, and you'll have enough money to invest in some pretty niche strategies.

The Characters
The game's character work is about on par with its plot work, but it has the benefit of being fleshed out passively as a consequence of the combat. Even if you're not a big fan of the fairly unadventurous tropes many of the characters are built around, you may find it hard to stay mad when they're jamming half the enemy fleet's targeting for you, or sniping missile boats from accross the map. I know I did.

The in-combat voice clips got on my nerves at first, but they over time they grew on me, and I wound up pretty happy with them as the rampant devestation they heralded increased in scope and range. Not that you can't turn them off; if there's one thing Sunrider isn't wanting for, it's options.

Bugs/Issues
The game has recieved balance and bugfix reports after release, and it's pretty well rounded. There remain one or two potential crashes related to the combat layer; about once in two hours I would guess, you may hit a script bug that quits you to desktop. However, the game has a very robust auto-save system, and a crash will set you back a few seconds at most.

Summary
This game is fun, good looking, free, and dare I say it: well made. Why not pick it up and see if you like it? You've little to lose except a bit of time, and if it grabs you enough to take that from you, wouldn't you say it's earned its price?

If does take your fancy, consider throwing a bit of coin at the developers' site. There's no requests for donations or cheap monitization gimmicks in the game, and if the money doesn't go straight to rewarding the devs for their good work, it'll most likely go towards designing more quality games.

reviewText:
I first discovered Sunrider through a gaming news site, during the middle of the Kickstarter. I followed it for a while, eventually downloading the demo. Though nowhere near as refined as it currently is, the combat and the story drew me in, and made me want more. It wasn't a hard decision to back it, in the end, and I haven't regretted it since.

Each of the characters have tropes and cliches making up their general personalities, However, that's not all there is to them. They each have life and depth, which, in my opinion, makes it worth fighting through even the toughest battle, just to see what happens with each of them next.

And believe me, the battles will be tough. Love in Space designed Sunrider to be a very difficult game, in which you always feel as if you're just about to be overwhelmed. I think they have succeeded at this, as I certainly never feel completely at ease during battle.

Still, there are different difficulty levels, if it's too much for you. I don't mind admiting that I switch to Easy on occasion, myself. However, if you're one of those people that finds nearly being overwhelmed constantly" too easy

reviewText:
I'll preface this review by noting that as a Visual Novel, this is NSFW - it may not be completely explicit, but there is enough for me to feel like I need to put that warning out there. So, that is definitely something to keep in mind when determining whether or not this is something you would like to play.

First of all, this is a genuinely free-to-play game. There is no catch, thanks to the successful Kickstarter. This means that there are no micro-transactions or other payments required to play - although I for one, am also financially supporting the Developers with other purchases. The plot is interesting though not necessarily spectacular. But the world is quite interesting - then again, I am always hugely interested in the lore and background of games, sometimes more than the game itself... The game has some pretty solid dialogue as well, including some incredibly funny lines. The post-credits and bonus scenes are also quite amusing. :D

The standard visual novel fare is present, with conversation options and topics and a variety of characters and a pretty interesting world to get involved in and learn about. But then Sunrider makes a sharp turn here, integrating mechs and turn-based strategy... quite well, actually. I'm nostagically reminded of games like Super Robot Wars on the GBA... a good thing, for me at least - I love those old turn-based strategy GBA games - and this includes most of the good parts of those games!

And it's not like the turn-based strategic combat is just tacked on for the heck of it - it can be quite fun and engaging too, though this wouldn't necessarily be the hardest turn-based strategy game around. There are a range of difficulty settings, from the extremely easy Visual Novel" mode (where you deal more damage and take less) to the very challenging "Hard" (which is actually... quite hard

reviewText:
10/10 has giant spaceships, space mechs, giant spaceships fighting space mechs, and boobs. Yep, there are plenty of those carried around by the helpful female cast of the game.

Seriously though Sunrider: First Arrival is a combination of a visual novel and a grid-based, turn-based combat...in space! Yeah! Everyone loves space combat, and if you don't, there's plenty of boobs to carry you along. The game is obviously for you if you are into both genres (especially considering the game is being distributed at the low low price of free), while I can still see fans of either genre enjoying the game's other half.

I am somewhat at a disadvantage here for having almost 0 experience with visual novels (the only thing I know about them is that they come in boobed and non-boobed variants, and the female characters featured, when lined up, display a vast array of hair color envying even rainbows featured in the proudest of gay pride parades). Being unable to tell you how the visual novel experience holds up compared to other visual novels out there, but I can at least tell you that it is functional, for a harem-ish (I assume) with a vast array of female characters archetypes to interact with.

Unfortunately, for players like me, who are drawn in purely to command space fleets and not the promise of boobs (okay, maybe a little bit of boobs too), the game revolves more on its VN experience than its tactical space combats, and those combats only serve to bridge and progress storylines, and act as a means for you to get those cuties to start talking stuff. While the amount of units and their upgrades are for surely not lacking, the overall experience suffered as it had to share its space with the VN part. Still, I'm not complaining here, I got some fun hours out of it (especially if you, like the filthy, brainless peasant I am, drop the difficulty all the way to the lowest and casually mop the space floor with hostile super battleships and carriers and the like in-between rooting for your potential waifu(s))

Overall, considering its price (free), I'd say it's worth a try so long as you are not overly allergic to VNs.

reviewText:
My first venture into the Visual Novel category. Technically, it's half VN/half turn-based tactics. This was a big point as I figured the most similar game I've played previously was Fire Emblem: Path of Radiance. Between that and my familiarity with the Phoenix Wright games, I figured I was prepared for the type of story I was going to get.

I was not prepared.

Maybe my first clue should have been the all female cast on the promo screen, or the characters alternating between school girl outfits (on a battleship?) and Evangelion-style jumpsuits. I quickly realized I'm probably sufficiently older than the target demographic for this game.

You play as the last good guy in the universe, apparently. Every other male character onscreen is the enemy, or at least kept arms-distance away from the plot. You DO get to interact with many young women, several of whom are pining for you to some degree. I was expecting Phoenix Wright and instead got Fate/Stay Night. There should be a distinction for Visual Romance Novel, because it's about as self-serving. Oh and there's space politics.

To be fair, the dialogue does discuss plot elements of some moral ambiguity, and does give reasonable choices in the same regard. Though since I haven't finished the game I don't know how those choices play out. The overarching story has a lot in common with the aforementioned Fire Emblem game (remnants of a conquered land seek to stop the invading army from unlocking an ancient power by requesting the aid of the other superpower, and there's a princess) but is played here with more nuance. The benefit of VN format, I guess.

The tactics maps are the top reason I keep playing. They are challenging without feeling unbalanced on the default setting. The music's pretty awesome, too.

Overall, this game is pretty middle-of-the-road. It didn't persuade me to the VN genre, and doesn't offer enough that I could recommend it to someone who doesn't already seek it out. I don't think it's bad, it's just not for me.

reviewText:
One of the best free to play games I have played. I would recommend if you are a fan of the following 3 things: anime, space games, and tactics games.

+Fairly good story with character development and choices between battles
+Flows well so that you want to keep playing to see what happens next
+Plenty of spaceships, mechs, missiles, and lasers, fun grid-based tactical combat
+Variety of weapon and ability types with pros/cons to each, making for some strategy
+Many choices of upgrades for your ship and weapon types between battles
+Some voiced dialogue in battles
+FREE to play singleplayer game, can't beat that and I would like to see more

-Graphics are nothing stellar but not bad either, some limited animations
-No voiced dialogue for story or outside of battle
-Voices in battle can be repetitive at times as they occur for every player and enemy action.
-Some character limitations (main character is male, almost every other character is an anime girl)
-No multiplayer (doesn't bother me but some may find that strange in free to play)

reviewText:
Short Answer:
First 17+ Visual Novel I've seen available on steam (Yes there will be nudity~)

Dating Sim/ Tactical RPG (Mechs, Starships, Tight Space suits that remind me of Muv Luv and Evangelion where do I sign up?)

Very good story as well as a superb soundtrack really sets the mood

Some Heroine Archetypes I noticed: (Osananajimi) Childhood Friend, Kuudere, Dandere, Tsundere, (Hellz yeah!) Pervert (very funny girl xD) and Loli (one thats more annoying then cute)

Partial voiced in English that is pretty good and not ear grating (like almost every hentai that was english dubbed)

Easy to understand combat system (note projectile weapons such as nuke and missles can be shot down by flak so dont believe that 100% hit ratio all the time unless you take down thier flak that is)

10/10 would buy it if they asked for money (which they wont the game is free and will remain the same with the future installments)

Only draw back is it's not fully complete it's a 3 part game and atm the first 2 have been added and in the near future we should see part 3.

Long Answer:
Sunrider: First Arrival has by far surprised me I've been waiting for games like Little Busters and Kanon to get licensed to steam but when I came across this I did not expect to not only get a visual novel but one that comes with tactical RPG gameplay and fanservice. (uncensored in some cases so be carefull if you play this at work then again the sticky note says 17+) It really reminds me of Muv Luv and Baldr Force in terms of Visual Novel but what makes it more interesting is that its voiced partially in english thats not to the point that it grates my ears like most dubbed Hentais. I was also surpised to find out that it wasnt made in Japan so +1 to the developers on this game for not only attempting to make a game but for making it free as well. So you must be asking should I play this game? Is it worth my time? Well if you like playing visual novels or eroge for that matter I really reccomend giving this game a chance also this game is free and from researching it looks like future chapters will still remain free (sorry its not the full game only a small part of it) so I really suggest it. Lastly the gameplay is pretty fun and simple to understand just something I want to note is when you are shooting missles or nukes beware enemys do come with flak which means they are able to shoot some missles if not all of them down so its just something to note that their 100% hit rate doesnt really apply to those types of weapons. The best way to counter that is you get an engineer pretty early in the game I say for the 3rd or 4th battle her name is chigara Ashada I believe that is able to hack in and turn off their flak guns however its for the ships you choose so other enemy ally ships could also shoot them down if they are near the target you are shooting at. In closing I really have to say this despite the game being free if they were to sell this game not saying that they will I would totally buy it.

reviewText:
I was coming into this expecting something much less than what it was. Gosh, was I fooled.

This game is in dire need of optimization and further patches - it can chug worse than a Prius trying to haul a mobile home. The UI doesn't register your clicks sometimes, and the save / load screen could use some work as well. The battles can be 'Nintendo Hard' to the point where if you don't optimize your ships a certain way, you will not survive.

But, it is FREE - and for some great space battle thrills, and a hard hitting story - Sunrider has definately earned the hours that I've poured into this game. The usual anime tropes and character archetypes show up here, right down to hearing 'I'm not doing this because I like you' in the middle of a firefight, and not only that - but a few raunchy scenes make their way into this release. Thankfully, while at the end of the day this is still a japanese style VN - the game isn't overloaded with these moments, and doesn't seek to be a hentai.

The story combines perfectly with the fighting, almost every mission feels like a fight for your life while being hunted by a fleet far superior to your single capital ship, and a few brave allies in their 'Ryders'.

By the time I saved the Agamemnon, I felt like a hero with a cause.

Tl;dr

FOR YOU IF:

- You have a fondness for grid based space battle games (ex: Super Robot Taisen Series)
- You enjoy japanese style visual novel series backed up by decent characters, a great story, and deep music

NOT FOR YOU IF:

- You are phobic towards the usual anime tropes verging on the NC-17 level
- You hate hard games and you are too stubborn to use the difficulty settings

reviewText:
I remember seeing the Kickstarter for this and liking the idea, though I was practically destitute at the time so I couldn't donate myself. I am glad to say that the LIS team has made some thing really special here. Its not without its flaws but this is an excellent sign for the quality of this series in particular and western VNs in general. Helps that its also a damn good turn based strategy game as well.

If I had to nitpick, the main antagonist, whom I refer to as Char on heroin, is overblown to the point of absurd humor even considering the classic mecha anime tone of the game's story. Where most of the characters are pretty well written I think he kind of stands out as a blatant and rather unamusing charactiture. The voice acting, which only exists in battle segments much like the confirmations of RTS units, is also hit and miss. Depends on your tolerance for US anime-dub quality voice work. Some voices are far better than others.

The plot overall is entertaining, most characters are likable. The battles are actually very demanding, Ive heard of many people being forced to turn down the difficulty later on. I happen to like the mecha design, very reminiscent of Armored Core in many ways. The music is stunning, a highlight of the game. I found the character art a mixed bag, though nothing is so bad as to be distracting. There are severe frame rate issues in battles, but I am told this is being worked on and its not like TBS games require twitch reflexes anyway.

Overall highly recommended. If you like VNs, this is a promising story to follow. If you like TBS games there is a damn good one under the hood here, and maybe you can broaden your horizons with the VN elements.

Oh yeah, and it's free. Now we wait for the Space Whale DLC I keep hearing about.

REVIEW UPDATE FOR MASK OF ARCADIUS:

Starting off, I have a lot of great things to say about this second part of three, but first the bad. There are a number of memory leaks and other crashes in the new gameplay segments. I am sure these will be patched but I reccomend caution and liberal saving.

Now then, the good stuff. The game is challenging as ever, introducing new unit types to further ruin your day, like support mechs with debuffs and curses. This is a good thing, disregard the forum whining. Story is still engaging, with a lot of improvement in the characterization of Captain Shields and nice moments for the whole cast, even the antagonists.

Oh, and Char on Heroin is still hard to take seriously, so it's nice that the other two antagonists pick up his slack on the depth and likability department.

Frame Rate issues are still present, but massively improved from initial release. I still find this game running on open source VN software to be something of a miracle.

So yeah, heartily reccomend this second part of the game. I am actually anxious to see the third. Maybe we shall see one of those damn space whales, at last.

reviewText:
Definitely enjoyed it, but had some troubles with the battles on Normal mode. I suggest playing in Novel Mode or Easy the first time around, because it's harder than it appears. You also need to save as much CP as you can early on, because the last two missions have a ton of enemies that you need to get rid of quick in order to progress.

One big problem I had with the battle system is that (in my opinion) the ratio between enemy kills and how much it costs to upgrade wasn't very even. Even if you kill alot of enemies, repair costs at the end can take away a huge chunk of the profits and the number of turns you take in battle also determines the amount of CP you get. So you end up blitzing through battles to complete the mission as fast as possible each time, which nets alot of CP for the Vanguard Cannon and Drones, but you can potentially miss out on alot of money.

The costly upgrade rates between the Sunrider and the Ryders, plus the necessity of buying missiles means you'll barely be upgrading anything through your playthrough and spending most of them on restocking missiles. The best upgrades I found when playing were increased missile stock for the Sunrider and HP upgrades for everything, since those were cheap. Upgrading anything else such as weapon damage/accuracy/energy, flak and armor were too costly to be effective. Later on in the game you also have to pay to use Repair Drones instead of having them for just 750 CP, and that further depleted the already finite money I had even more. Even at the end of the game I was barely scraping by with barely enough money to afford missiles and could not afford to upgrade anything as the battles just got harder.

Besides the problems I had with the actual battle system and strategy, for a Free English VN this is very very good. It's definitely worth playing and the story is pretty interesting. The VA's are pretty good too; better than what you'd expect for an English VN.

It needs more Icari scenes though. The amount of Icari scenes compared to everyone else made me kinda sad. There were a couple times during the game when you could talk to every Ryder pilot, but Icari wasn't around when I needed her. I'm not sure if it was because of the choices I made in the game or not when getting Icari, but it made me sad when no option to talk to her popped up.

All in all, this is a great game, but start off on Novel Mode or Easy for the first time around so you don't get bogged down in one battle for several hours like I did. Enjoy the story first and foremost before anything else. There was only one doable sidequest in the game, and I'd like to have a few more so players could bolster their resources for later game.

tl;dr version: It's like Galaxy Angel meets Advance Wars meets Valkyria Chronicles. It's good.

reviewText:
This game has a number of issues you should consider, as they killed any appeal the game had for me before too long.

First, the characters and story are fairly bland, and many character's voices will annoy you easily, if not the first time, then after the tenth or hundredth time, and many of them are filled with meme phrases that personally annoyed me terribly.

Second, the actual gameplay.  While the gameplay works in the small-scale, when it attempts to have larger scale battles later on, it fails.  This is largely due to the ubiquitous use of missiles, which are extremely long-range, extremely accurate attacks meant to be rare and used sparingly.  However, in the later stages, the enemy spawns infinite reinforcements each with 4 or 5 missiles.  There is a stage in particular that is just boring and infuriating, because the moment you end your first turn, you WILL lose at least one unit to a barrage of more than a dozen missiles.  And unlike other attack animations, you cannot skip the missile's travel animation, leading to a wait of upto 10 seconds for each missile.  Having timed it, a turn for the enemies on a certain stage, skipping as many animations as possible, took two full minutes of sitting there watching missiles zoom across the screen.

Finally, the code needs polish. A lot of polish.  I am running an i7 processor and a GTX780, with plenty of RAM and an SSD, there is no reason for this performance.  In large battles, the animations become extremely choppy, and this happens when playing for extended periods as well. This also causes complete animation failures, and UI glitches, such as missiles never appearing, units not visibly moving, the commands menu disappearing, accuracy rates being displayed incorrectly or not being displayed at all, and unit buffs not being displayed.  While the game never crashed, it performed so poorly that when combined with these other issues just made the experience completely irredeemable.

To address the massive amount of attack spam, and long wait times between turns, a friend of mine has created a helpful guide to turn off animations. Manually.  The guide can be found here:   http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=286831703

reviewText:
Like this game.  The turned based battles.  The option to upgrade both the Sunrider and the ryder's seperately.  There are also so visual novel type choices, decisions to make which I haven't determined if one choice really effects the story over another choice yet, but I am assuming the path of the story takes a slight detour if not an entire new ending.

I like that there are a lot of strategic decisions to make on the battlefield, such as which weapon to use on which enemy, how far to move in any one turn, when to use a special power, or even if to in certain battles, as that takes up energy that you don't get back until you earn more.

Different battles also have different objectives.  Some are eliminate enemy, others are protect certain ships, etc.

I do find it funny that two of the ryder pilots are dressed in almost the exact same looking pilot outfits, and look almost exactly like, even down to the exact same hairstyle, as two of the Evangelion pilots in the anime Neon Genesis Evangelion.  Gee, wonder were the makers of Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius got their charater ideas from.  =D

In short, I have been playing this for a few hours now and am still enjoying it.  Have failed one battle objective 3 times now, but I keep coming back to try different tactics.  I reccommend this game for those who are looking for a good anime, turned based strategy game.  Aren't to many of those being made for the PC now.

Game developers now just want to make retro, 8 bit games, point and click adventure crap, or RPG eye candy that is more movie and battle animations than gameplay, where you need the latest and greatest video card to handle the animation and CG.

For those that would like to get back to real strategy gaming, with anime and some story thrown in, I definately recommend this game.

reviewText:
Having only just finished my first playthrough, I wonder if I'm quite worthy of writing a review yet, but here goes!

A few months back I decided to really get into the VN scene on steam, and this one was chosen admittedly for its price. Nothing aids a shopping spree quite like the word FREE, and along with a few other Sekai Project works, this one found its way into my library and I started it just a few weeks back.

Let me tell you, having just finished the second episode, I am bouncing around the room with excitement!

At first, the sprite-based artwork didn't appeal to me much, but after some time they begin to grow on you. This also applies to the characters. At first it seemed like each was just fulfilling their role as a walking anime stereotype, with examples including the hyperactive girl, the quiet genius, the tsundere, the stickler for the rules and some others. But soon enough I was joining in with all their little speeches in-combat and was genuinely interested in how their character would grow. This game also breaks from the traditional in that it really feels like your mission is the liberation of the galaxy, rather than just choosing the options that will lead you to your desired girl of choice. The game doubles up genres and gives you a turn-based strategy as well, which came as a welcome treat for me.

The music in this game was solid from the start. Each tune perfectly matches the surroundings and really immerses you in what's going on at the time. I remember the first time I used the Vanguard Cannon ability, and the change in music was nothing short of overwhelming. You can imagine members of your crew cheering with every victory gained.

The moral side of the choice-making is very clear. Generally it's between the right thing to do and fulfilling the mission, which always leads to debates about who you are as a person, but thank goodness for multiple save files! You can try any and every possible option and still feel like you haven't quite lost your humanity.

In terms of cons, the only noticeable one is that sometimes in combat missions the game will crash and force you to quit, but other than quickly restarting, this doesn't set you back very far as the saving system is usually on the ball.

Overall, I give a 9/10 for amazing music, brilliant last-minute plot twists, the strategy elements, and of course, the Vanguard cannon.
Damn, I love that cannon

reviewText:
This game confuses me. I don't know why it's free.  I would pay for this.

Short version:  Anime-style visual novel with a light but surprisingly satisfying hex-grid turn-based tactics game built in.

Several hours in and I am REALLY enjoying this thing and can't yet see where the F2P comes in.  I think this might be something like the Katawa Shoujo thing that got made and released for free by fans of the genre, maybe?  Either way, it's great value.

Be advised: Typical anime harem tropes are a plenty in the story part, for better or worse. But the choices seem plenty and benign, and I love researching upgrades.

reviewText:
Everyone should play Sunrider. For first: it is a free game. One of few games funded on kickstarter that is not a scam to take your money. A true testament of people who really want to be independent devs. It is also a good scifi tactical rpg/visual novel hybrid. Of course limitations of renpy engine can be seen and game relly demands a strong PC, despite it's apperiance.

Special notice for soundtrack and sound effects. For a game with low budget, that was realesed free of charge, it stands on top level.

To all of you on kickstarter devs. Take a hint from this game. It was made right on time and devs don't demanded more money for it, than they get through crowdfunding. THIS IS HOW YOU DO THIS. Not like Broken Age, when you get milions, deliver one chapter, after the deadline and complain that your fanbase is asking question.

Sunrider is to way to go. A bright light.

reviewText:
If you have any interest in Visual Novel, you have to give this a try.

Pros:
+ Free, totally.
+ Great Soundtracks. (freely available on game files Steam\SteamApps\common\Sunrider\game\Music)
+ In-depth storyline.
+ So many girls around. Oh wait...

Cons:
- Inconclusive story. A part of trilogy, anyway, but still....
- Mediocre battle mechanic.
- Engine is so unoptimized. How come I'm getting low FPS in 2D battle!!! for a Visual Novel genre?

If you've ever played XCOM, Front Mission or Final Fantasy Tactics, this is similar. A hexagonal turn based strategy game wrapped in Visual Novel genre.

The battle mechanic is too simple for my taste, but understandably since this is not intended as full-blown strategy game like XCOM. You control some basic Ryders alongside the mother ship, and along with the storyline you'll be sent to battle menu to arrange team into the 'board' with variety of objectives depending on where you are on the story. There are some pre-planning involved, as in don't put Sora on the front of the enemies as her Ryder is weak, yet deadly when sniping from afar, or put your Mother Ship in the middle of the battle. Mostly the objectives would be to wipe out the entire opposing team, but sometimes you have to escort someone to safety.

The quest system is there, fairly promising but falls short. After certain points of the game, you'll be given a world map, where you can pick where you go. There you can work on quests that when you complete it, you'll receive rewards. The game maybe was initially designed  to be offering multiple paths to progress with this quest system that you can manually pick, but then again it does not give any real impact since the ending stays the same. Moreso, the game gives you multiple choices to pick to reply in many situations, but again, nothing's changed significantly except the one near the end of the game.

The most amusing part is for me about the story - and how the characters interact with each others especially Kaito to Ava (given their notable past - close relationship). I would have hoped the developers could deliver more story about each characters' background, though, especially Sora. That said, I find the game has some in-depth lores, and you have to pay a bit of attention so as not to miss anything and be clueless later.

And lastly, I find the game performance is pretty horrible. Ranging from constant crashes that forced me to reload from last save (god knows I've done that how many times) and truly poor controller support (who on earth wouldn't like to play VN genre while laying comfortably on the bed?). So yeah, save often and don't count on that quick save feature. Don't forget to save on multiple files, you'll understand why when you see the save menu.

However, I could find nothing but a resounding yes to question 'is the game worth playing?'. If you love Visual Novel, definitely give this a try.

reviewText:
It’s very rare I write reviews but Sunrider deserves one. When I first seen this game I was sceptic, but since it was free to download I thought why not give it a go? I’m glad I did.

If I had to describe this game in two words it would be amazingly addictive. Out of all the games I’ve played over the past few years, this is without a doubt one of the best. It’s easy to pick up and challenging.

It’s a turn based strategy game set in the future. A bit like Gundam Wing, politics included. The storyline is second to none and the soundtrack compliments the game well, not to mention there are some good plot twists (even I didn’t see coming). You also get to make your own choices which make it a bit more personal and keep you involved. The Characters have interesting backstories and questionable personalises (in a good way). There is some adult humour involved (mostly with Doctor Claude Triello) but other than that it’s toned down innocently.

I’m really looking forward to hearing more about this game and playing more. It would be nice if they continued it like the Mass Effect Series or even made a TV show. I would happily pay for Sunrider. The good news? it’s a free game so download and give it a try you won’t regret it.

All for one and one for all (Asaga Oakrun)

Marks out of ten? Over 9000

reviewText:
AS OF VERSION 4.2 \ whatever version when I post this

CONS

Every game around, I always play the hardest difficulty it can offer.
This game's 'hard' mode is one of the most frustratingly hard modes I have ever played.
Hell. I played The Last Of Us on the hardest difficulty and that one wasn't too bad. Just annoying sometimes. Starcraft 2 Brutal? fun fun hard.  This game hard? = Oh. 5th-10th try on this map again? damn it all.

Perhaps it's my strategies(or lack thereof) when fighting the enemy. But every few maps instead of trying to beat it on hard mode after the X,XX number of times. I'll get frustrated and go into cheat mode aka Story Mode (cuz hey it is a visual novel too!)

BUT despite beating a few maps in Story Mode, thus earning almost the Max amount of $ one can earn for that map to purchase so many more upgrades had I tried beating it in hard mode. Upgrades purchased using that money mean almost squat to me for the next map(s) afterward on hard.  Sure I may barely be able to scratch by the next map or so but then once again I may be so frustrated to play back in story mode just to get as much money as possible to perhaps, possibly defeat the next 1 or 2 maps on hard.

Perhaps it needs a more balance between money earned per mission\kill, and\or maybe a few more side missions you can do before each campaign mission as then you could be able to actually play the game in hard mode 100%.

When playing a map, defeating the objective without killing everybody. I find the very, very low amount of $ earned from the enemies still alive \ surrended units to be awful.  In the story you can kinda choose to be merciful (from saving people from slavers, choosing to save the vessel full of kids)   So instead no incentive to finishing a map's objective as fast as possible. Instead this game encourages me to massacre EVERYBODY.

^^^^
at the writing of this review, version 4.2 states that it is very low $ gained from non killed enemies. Thus encouraging you to kill everybody.

It's sometimes\usually hard to click on a character, as you have to click on their outline instead of the grid box they are on. sometimes I end up clicking a character 'above elow' the character intended

PROS

Nice anime silliness story, I enjoy it.

Awesome visuals, but sometimes even with auto skip it's still takes a while to get through a battle

Boobs. Boobs everywhere. oh and Bellys, Bellies? too

I lied theres no boobs. maybe in the other games.

reviewText: Sunrider: First Arrival, is in my opinion, one of the best, Visual Novel/ RPG's on Steam. It is shaping up to be a great game, and aside from a few bugs, and some performance issues, I think the game is pretty much good to go. Sunrider: FA is currently free, so if you are interested in trying a visual novel/ RPG type of game, this might be a good bet. There is a decent Strategy aspect to the combat, that makes it not just hours of chatting back and fourth between characters. Overall I would recommend this game to anyone interested in, visual novels, JRPG's, anime, japan, mechs, space, or any variation there of. Again, Sunrider, is currently free on Steam, so now is as good a time as ever to try it.\n\nNote: This game contains some adult themes, and nudity, Play at your own risk.

reviewText:
I'm a Sunrider Kickstarter backer.  This version appears to be the latest beta with some adjustments to the upgrade costs.  The story and tactical gameplay are fun, with lots of optons for different tactics and upgrade paths.  The difficulty settings allow for easy or extremely challenging battles, so you should be able to find a play style that appeals to you.  You may want to lower the music volume so you can hear the pilots' commentary during battle.

You will need to learn where the game expects you to click when selecting units for command or targetting, and there is some lag when many units are on the battle screen.  There is also (at the moment) a lack of documentation on some of the options available to the support units, but their use should become clear with a little experimentation.  I expect most of these issues to be addressed as the game continues development.

Highly recommended!

reviewText:
So first I have to say this could be a very good game.
Their are something to keep in mind though. First this is a very new game so their is bound to be problems.

First lag OMG THE LAG. I run games with better graphics at around 60FPS but this was just horrible. Itwas around 20-30 shooting down to only 5-10 sometimes. Fix some of the lag issues and it would be great. But its new so didnt expect it to be perfect.

2nd the fullscreen i'm not sure if this is for everyone or just me but the full screen doesnt work for me. I can only look at one section of the screen. So playing fullscreen mode wasnt an option. I like my desktop but i really like being submerged into games.

3rd I would say the battle animations. I really would like a fast forward on it. Not a full skip due to the fact that I'm sure they worked hard on the animations. But some sort of fast forward.

4th the miss clicking. This was mainly due to the lag, but cant get over it. I had to restart so many fights just because i used the wrong command or an attack that costed me the fight.

This game has alot of potential so please keep working at it. I would really like to see the finish product. I hope you can at least fix the lag in a few weeks.

reviewText:
For an absolutely free game this game is really fun and good.
If you like Anime style stuff, sci-fi stuff, mecha, spaceship battles, and kawaii uguu~ waifu you should definitely give this game a try.
The slow turn-based style game is also very much like old school JRPGs as well and give the game a comfy as ♥♥♥♥ feel to it.
There is a lot going for this game IMO compared to similar non-Japanese VN games with combat on Steam.
1) Voice actors are not as kawaii uguu~ as Japanese ones, but they are at least decent, even if some of the dialogue itself can be slightly cringe-worthy
2) The art style is pretty good IMO, again considering non-Japanese origin and including combat, compared to say games like Magical Dairy, Science Girls, and Planet Stronghold, this game definitely has the best art style and most kawaii girls (admittedly the non-combat VNs on steam have superior art/girls [Go Go Japan, etc]).
3) The art style and designs for the spaceships and mechs are pretty cool looking and well done
4) The sound effects are very good in this game, and help a lot with immersion in space battles IMO
5) Even though some people complain about the animations and voicing during attacks, I really enjoy them and think they good and fun

reviewText:
Do you have an interest in visual novels? If you do, then you owe it yourself to give Sunrider: First Arrival a try. For a free, visual novel that's still in beta, this game is looking very promising.

The story, art, and characters are all well done, enjoyable and memorable. The turn-based battles involving the grid overview add a little more interactivity to the game as opposed to the standard 'read text and then make decisions' found in most typical visual novels. I enjoyed the game more for the story and the characters rather than for the turn-based battle system however, though the battles themselves were decently enjoyable up until the last few battles nearing the end of the game, where things began to get really tedious (and somewhat unforgiving). The fully voiced unit/character responses during the battle sequences are also a nice touch, and serve to give fights a more personal feeling, as characters begin to sound more desperate/concerned the more their ship's/ryder's health declines.

Those who wish to avoid or have no interest in the battle aspect of this game may be disappointed to know that there is currently no way to skip battles and just read through the game as a visual novel. However, there are difficulty settings which can make progressing through battles more rapid, or, if you're the type who really enjoys formulating strategies, much more difficult where every move must be carefully calculated in order to succeed.

Overall, Sunrider: First Arrival is a title you may want to keep an eye on, as the game is already highly enjoyable and playable in its current state. There's drama, comedy, tragedy, and moral decisions to be found in the main story, and I found myself immersed in the plot so much to the point where I felt responsible for the decisions I had to make during the course of the game. Not only that, but I also felt that I actually cared about what happened to the characters; each of them have their distinct personalities and somehow manage to be endearing in their own ways...

Whether it's due to the epic soundtrack, the 'cutesy anime-style character drawings', the drama of the story, the turn-based battle system, or any combination of these, Sunrider: First Arrival is a game that truly deserves your attention. It might not be completely polished (I experienced some kind of glitching or slowdown in many of the battle sequences), but for a game of this high quality to be made available completely for free is something I'd consider as a most welcome (and possibly unforgettable) gift.

Play it:
- For the story.
- For the art, characters, and music.
- If you like or have an interest in anime.

Don't play it:
- If you only want to play a polished, turn-based strategy game. (It's not bad, but you'll mostly be spending your time reading.)

reviewText:
This is s story based Japan anime game with tactical strategy in between. Now for sombody who hate story based games (for example, those made by bioware), I am surprised to see that I actually like the story in this game. I am still trying to figure out why. As for the tactical strategy of the game, it is relatively interesting. Each rider has various kind of weapons and abilities which allow various combinations and strategies.

Now, for the bad side, first the interface, there are numbers so small on the screen that I cannot see them. I plugged my lap top on a television and it became worse, could not even see the hit percentages. The other faling aspect is that it is hard to predict the effectiveness of your attack. They are many different weapons and counter measure, that it's hard to understand and plan ahead their interaction. You can even have situation where a weapon that does 200 points of damage does more than 200 points. So the computations are hard to anticipate, more explanations would have helped. The AI is OK, I just find it very annoying when they target always the same rider, especially the pheonix.

There are a lot of powerup and upgrades, a bit too much, sometimes you can have two way to get the same results. For example, you could increase your rider's energy, but also reduce the energy cost of weapons. Which is 2 ways to do the same thing. As for the story engine, I am surprised how they managed to have a strong story based game with few art, interesting for low budget games. Everything is basically written in the text, sometimes a few additional picture would have helped to know what is going on. Semi manga style drawing would have been cool even if only black and white, but I understand that artwork is expansive.

There is still 1 quick fix that could be done, show the face of the talking character (above or under the name). It sometimes becomes very confusing who is talking to who. Having a framed picture change after each line of dialog would help, and would not require additional art.

Finally, the game is pretty much linear, in the early game, you had a choice between 3 missions, I would have hoped to get those choices more often in the game. Also the story choices lead to the same results most of the time. I am not asking for something like mass effects, but at least get different results and rewards from your choices.

If you like turn based strategy games and you are a fan of Japanese animation and culture, I strongly recommend this game.

Enjoy and have fun!

reviewText:
I've played my fair share of visual novels, dating sims, setting up a comedy club and things that should not be seen by younger players you name it. Sunrider: First Arrival is your typical visual novel where you find yourself in galactic civil war, commanding ships and mechs that is styled with a mixture of chess and battleships, ethical choices and attractive young pilots. Huh, thinking about it, guess it's not your typical visual novel. If you've played War of the Human tanks, conflicts are similar except turned based. Furthermore, it's free, everybody likes free stuff.

Pros:
+Mechs
+Engaging sci-fi conflict
+Multiple and interesting heroines
+Fantastic VGM
+Ethical choices
+Challenging. Being outnumbered and out gunned.
+Free
+Bewbs

Cons:
-Short. To be honest, I was hoping for it to be longer but it's a tad short.
-Challenging. Being outnumbered and out gunned.


Note: I'm a little bias here as I'll love Visual Novels and anime. Also, if anyone has played visual novels like Koihime Musou, Sunrider is a futuristic version except, less women and less eroge. Furthermore, if you've played War of the Human tanks, battles scenarios are similar except turned based.

reviewText:
FANTASTIC!!! FANTASTIC!!! FANTASTIC!!!
This game was a complete joy to play from start to finish... and this is only part 1. Everything in this game was done extremly well. The characters themselves looked amazing, they felt real, I was happy when they were happy, sad when they were sad... thats when you know this game works. The writing for this game was superb. Characters interacted with each other in a very real and realteable way (minus a couple of spelling errors I might have seen).
Even more, the music that accompanied this game is brilliant. The second a new soundtrack hit, I immediatley knew if the scene was going to be comedic, sad, or encouraging.... man those battle soundtracks got my blood boiling every time (to destroy the PACT that is).
This game really does have everything, great characters, great writing, beautiful character, robot, and scenery designs, all accompanied by great music that fit every single scene perfectly.

I'm truyl dissapointed I was unaware of this game when it was a kickstarter... I would have given as much money as I could have to play this game.

10/10

I can't wait for the next installment of this game!!!!

reviewText:
I have played quite a bit of the new version and all of the original and i just couldn't stand the weird popup screens that kill your game, the game has those bugs, and well they bug me, no pun intended. Other then that, the story is piling on and on, only getting better. The characters, while having tropes seem to be interesting. New enemy units have been introduced... However this is missing the one thing that all mecha anime have: a enemy team with Unique mecha like the protaginists. There are a main enemy and the one pirate girl, but i want more colorful mecha to fight!!!! The game is still tricky, an interesting and welcome thing to most people. The only other problem i have is The animation and voice acting. I understand that this is a kickstarter and it doesn't have much money, if i could provide i would, however i seem to be broke at the moment. Even so the animation is almost non-existent, and some of the voice acting is really bad. reviewText:
Sunrider: first Arrival

Space? Check. Anime characters? Check. Mechs? CHECK!

Sunrider: first Arrival is a space based RPG where the player gets to command the Sunrider carrier ship and save the galaxy from the evil PACT, all with the help of some anime schoolgirls and their death dealing Mechs known as Ryders.

Players get to make RPG-like morality based decisions such as save some civilians, or maybe kill them for a greater good. Of course the characters have their cliche ridden responses but this is acceptable and entertaining if anime drama is mildly interesting to you. The game soundtrack is suitably grand with a few different themes, but you may end up muting it after a while as the tracks are short and loop quickly. Voice acting is fairly limited as the story is told via text and visual effects.

The combat screen is where this game really shines. Units are presented on a grid, and each has a limited number of action points to spend on movement and attacks. Each offensive action triggers a brief anime style cut scene showing the unit making an attack as the crew member delivers a line of dialogue. There aren't many of these so they repeat frequently during a long battle, though who really gets tired of hearing 'Imma firing mah laser!'?

Fighting battles will be a fairly familiar process for players that are used to turn-based games, but the design of the interface often gets in the way of quick play - why have a unit only be selectable by clicking on a tiny area near it's middle? Or why have the weapon icons selectable only by clicking a tiny area somewhere above their middle? It's simply bad design that will infuriate you when it takes five attempts to get the game to register your click. Where are the shortcut keys? Why does the action skip over enemies' misses, but makes you click/space bar after they land a hit? Why are the unit health and action point bars so difficult to see and why oh why do they get covered over by a unit in the square below? Despite these issues the underlying combat is well designed, providing a strong challenge on normal difficulty.

Winning a battle yields a reward based on your performance which you can spend to upgrade your carrier and Ryders' defensive and offensive abilities. The selection including upgrades to armour, action points, weapons damage and accuracy. Increasing your battle effectiveness and helping you progress through the game.

Sunrider would benefit from some polishing up, and no doubt the developers will do so in the future, especially if they wish to make a series of these games. Despite that it's engaging and fun to play, and as a Free to Play game is highly recommended.
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sunrider is a turn based strategy visual novel, part of an episodic series still in development.
If that didn't turn you away already then this game is probably something you will enjoy playing.

Story: a mishmash of every anime/visual novel cliche from random bursts of world destroying powers and every stereotype you have come to love and hate (with the exception of the yandere.....). However the setting and the actual game element to this vn sets it apart enough to feel fresh, although near the end of the 4th hour I was ready for the ending. Don't expect feels, don't expect enough NSFW to be of...ahem... use..... and don't expect the game element to carry it. There was no apparent or odd spelling/grammar errors and everyone felt real enough to care a little bit. Oddly there was one conversation option that didn't have any response and I was just greeted with the same previous options after choosing it.

Gameplay: The game is built in the Ren'Py engine, and it suffers for it. Everything is smooth and runs well enough during the actual novel bits but the moment the game element comes into play the fps drops the engine chugs and I was worried it would crash mid battle (although it never did). The battles have some thought put into them and there is depth here to be found, the problem is the game explains nothing; I didn't know what I should be pumping research points into (you don't even have enough cash to really develop anything anyways so just max out the armor options) nor did I know what flak or any other weird element did, just trial and error with different attack options until something clicks. It came down to me abusing chigara's skill that makes 1 enemy unit and movable and outside of a couple units (i.e. icara using melee 99% of the time) I just spammed lazers or kinetic depending on what did the most damage.
The game is highly dependent on RNG's and I started out on the hard setting, switched to normal, then switched to easy, and by the last two fights I was on novel mode because I couldn't be arsed hoping my attacks would hit and the enemies would miss. It is a shame and I feel like this is what holds the game back so much. Between the terrible slowdown repetitive battle cries from teammates and the terrible RNG battles became a chore once the novelty wore off.

Presentation: The music, is perfect. Simply put it fit the situations well the ed and op tracks were fantastic and the quality was up there with something I would expect to find in a AAA game. The art is also beautiful and some of the backdrops really are fantastic, the problem is there isn't enough of it and some of the backdrops seem terribly done and empty (the cafeteria for example) and it throws me off when the rest of the game is so perfect. There is a cute little bonus novel attached and I never felt like anything was ugly. The sound effects of the guns and missles firing and connecting feel satisfying and most of the voice overs were well done.


Conclusion: This is a niche game, its apparent from the combo of turn based gameplay and VN and its apparent from the setting. The engine really does hold this game back and the episodic nature will probably turn others away since there won't be a real" conclusion. However being that this is a free download if you are even considering giving this game a go just do it. There is a lot of apparent work and love from the developer(s?) on this project and if you don't really enjoy the game after all you didn't really lose out being that this is a quick free download of a fun quirky game. I enjoyed it enough to finish it through but unless the developer switches engines or fixes some very apparent issues I will probably not give the second half my time even though I enjoyed the first half enough to reccommend it.


TL;DR there are actually no space whales :["

reviewText:
Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius....

This is a fantastic story, well written, loveable characters, dramatic moments that really reel you in, and most of all! Gameplay aspect in a visual novel! I've always loved turn based strategy and this one pulls it off pretty well!

Even more so, I love so much about this series, the fact that they go as far as to give some voicing to give an accurate idea of what each character sounds like. Very nice touch.

Even though it is incomplete, I'm looking forward to the finished product and the next chapter to the Sunrider Saga!
