reviewText:
Managed to beat this game in a day, even though my game time says 0 hrs. What can I say? I saw this Visual Novel was free and downloaded it, expecting to get the biggest piece of ♥♥♥♥. Man, was I surprised to learn that this game actually ended up being quite decent. I won't lie, I had more fun playing this than I had so far in World End Economica even though this one is free, unlike WEE.

Pros:

- It's f*cking free
- Simple to understand gameplay
- Story doesn't try to reinvent the wheel. It's nothing new, but presented in a good way, easy for you to get into and actually be interested in it.
- Awesome OST. You know how a lot of these kinda games have awful music? Well, this ain't one of these. Enjoyed it from the beginning to the end
- Voice Acting is quite fine. Sure, not the best job I have ever seen, but far from the worst ever. I actually didn't even have to flinch even once in this game because of it. Some lines even made me laugh.
- Characters are likeable. Granted, they are somewhat stereotypical Japanese archetypes, but hell...I didn't mind. They even made fun about it in some of the character lines. (WHAT!? I am not doing this because I like you or something

reviewText:
The soundtrack for this VN is an absoulte master peice.
Example: http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=284873799
If your enjoyed the Mass Effect interaction with your crew, you will enjoy your personal time trying to figure out each character.
Now the major choices in this game will decide who basically lives and dies, but an important note is there is no right answer.
Justice is a gray line (as in there is no right or wrong answer).
Would you sacrifice a few live to save billions, would you leave behind one of your crew?
The game part is like Fire Eblem/Final Fansty Tactics. There is no xp system, but there is a money system that is based on how many targets you destoryed and the damage you sustained at the end of a battle. This mony is then used to buy upgrades/missles.
If you enjoy VN this is one you can not overlook. I just finnished by first playthrough and I can say I will be playing this again multiple times. Can't why for the next two to be released.
10/10 just for Imma firing my lazer refernce.

reviewText:
At first glance, Sunrider looks a lot like your average Waifu simulator in space.

Please, PLEASE find it in yourself to look past that first glance and take a closer look. You'll be glad you did. Coming from someone who is completely ambivalent towards the waifu aspect of the game, I have found this to be one of the most inspiring gaming experiences of recent months.

You play as Captain Kayto Shields, first-time commander of the newest, most hi-tech Assault Carrier in the Cera Space Force, the Sunrider. Unfortunately, disaster strikes and your home planet is overthrown by an evil expansive space empire known as PACT, casting you and your crew into the middle of a Galactic Civil War! Beginning with just your own ship to command, your hangar bay will fill gradually with mechs known as 'Ryders', whose female pilots you will meet at regular intervals as you journey to liberate your homeland from these foreign invaders!

Now... given that this game is free, you get a lot for your money. The combat system is very concise, straight-forward and user-friendly. Each ship and ryder in your fleet will have different abilities and be stronger against certain enemies than others. There are also RPG aspects as you can pay to upgrade the stats of both the Sunrider and any Ryders in her compliment, while black market traders offer you various bonus upgrades like high-end boosters or ammunition upgrades for your cannons. In addition to the gameplay being top notch, there is an interesting and exciting overarching plot which, while occassionally bogged down with things like bikini parties on the beach (because muh fanservice), is often driven by a very strong cast of both main and supporting characters facing the very serious moral and ethical dilemmas of war and intergalactic politics.

The downsides are few. The game tends to lag a bit in combat, which is annoying but not to the point of unplayability. Also if you are incredibly averse to either animé or the concept of waifu harem games, this very may well not be the game for you. But if you can look past it's faults, Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius will probably be one of the best free games you ever play.

reviewText:
Excellent game, not to mention the fact it is free to play. I have long been a Visual Novel player, and while I have found several bugs that slow down the gameplay, they are minor at best. The story is interesting, and the cast fun. While the game is mainly a single path, there are some choices to add interactivity and the backstory is quite interesting at times.

Best of all, with the story, is the art, and most importantly the music. Some of the best music I have ever heard in a VN. Worth playing just for the music alone; at least in my opinion.

Would recommend Sunrider: First Arrival to any visual novel and Turn-Based game lover. Until the next adventure!

reviewText: After playing Loren the Amazon Princess and Planet Stronghold both combat romance RPG's by Winter Wolves, I am pleased to recommend Sunrider: First Arrival another combat romance RPG. Loren gets 5 out of 5 stars while Stronghold and Sunrider both science fictions get 4 out of 5 stars. You can't beat Sunriders price. One way to enjoy the game more is to save the beginning of each combat battle then play each battle several times using different strategies which will allow you to discover the different tactical advantages of your team and ships. The use of stealth and close combat by one of the team members gets the blood flowing. Another of the team heals or causing electronic headaches for the enemy. Combined tactics that support other members of the team is the only way I have been able to beat the enemy. The romance just adds icing to the cake and bonds you to the charaters. Who in the world would not want a wacky group of women on board your vessel of destruction. Captain Kirk never had it so good but you can in Sunrider.

reviewText:
This is pretty much only my opinion from playing it so far.

(This game isn't the final version and so this mean game isn't completed and changes might that changes this game and make my review no longer valid)

Positive
-decent story
-fun combat
-choices
-a guys type of game due to theme of spamming girl characers
-pretty good music
-pretty good artwork for the ships and characters
-fair voice acting
-its a free game

Negatives
-Very strange lag during some combat missions and it lags even though your using a high end computer too

-Currently some missions are quite difficult due because of missle spamming that lasts a pretty long time and some enemies won't move and instead fire a  second set of missles at you

-Not too many side missions makes buying any missles or any single use items from the store very wasteful when you could use it for upgrades and get long term benefits

-Price spikes for things like the Flak Upgrades from 500 to 1000 is very unbalanced because the total pool of money is very limited

-Not too many side missions at all, making any money earned a very rare thing to have at all

-High Command cost of 2500 for using the Sunriders main cannon and it seems to be limited to hit 4 units and it instantly fires when selected and theres no preview of how far it'll go (no shown firing distance)  and it would cause the weapon to be very useless because you need to get pretty close to actually hit 4 targets in a striaght line and the damage is Capped so enemies missle spamming can actually do more damage to you compared to using it and has Almost limitless firing distance (positive thing is that it doesnt use energy to use, only command points)

-Not allowed to position your units the way you want to Before a mission giving you a big tactical disadvantage (meaning no pre-planned tactics before a mission)

Overall, dispite the negatives I can see that this game has great potential so it's recommended that you try it out since it is free. I wouldn't mind purchases dlc that opens up more story and gameplay if it meant helping the game improve.

(Again this is just a opinion from playing abit of this game, I already read that this isn't a finished/polished game yet so this opinion will end up being old at some point and this is Only from MY point of view so please no negative comments)

reviewText:
Likes:
Free.
A smooth learning curve that deepens considerably when you include the upgrade mechanics.
A good casual VN with entertaining gameplay.
The story gets interesting a few times with maturing themes.
Girl bits.
Great mechanical design.  The Ryders and especially the Sunrider are great designs.
A good homage to the anime Space Opera with many familiar archtypes for fans of that genre.

Dislikes:
Art style clashes a bit with the more mature segments of the game.
Character development is non-existent.
There are also several moments in the game where it feels like they might have tried to delve more into the characters and their interactions but then were suddenly cut from the game.
Voiced segments clash with the set personalities aboard ship.  I.E Icari is suddenly Tsundere in battle as opposed to the mature pseudo-sociopath she comes across when aboard ship.
Not enough resources to fully explore the upgrade system especially for first time players.
Beta, which means some bugs.  Ran into one where the Sunrider completely disappeared from the game.
They don't play that catchy J-pop song enough and when they do it cuts off during the enemy's turn.
Main characters voice during Vanguard Cannon scene is absolutely awful.
No ability to listen to game BGM's yet.
No dramatic changes from in game decisions as far as I could see.

So you might notice that several of the above mentioned dislikes would be a death knell for most VN's, seeing as they are story driven experiences.  If someone told me to pay up fifteen or twenty dollars for this game I would have said no.  Frankly I'd hesitate to pay five dollars.  The quality of the story and characters swings back and forth from Pretty Good" to "wut?" and that sense that the author kept all the character development in his head instead of in game is strong
date: even overwhelmning at times.  Or whole scenes between characters just ditched on the cutting room floor for some reason.  So why would I give this a thumbs up you might ask?\n\nBecause it is free.  As a free product
recommended: this makes for an enjoyable way to pass the time.  The gameplay itself is pretty solid and enough to keep you interested provided you are willing to learn the upgrade system.  Unfortunately the game doesn't give you enough cash to really take advantage of it.  Too many things on too many different craft to upgrade to really explore with what they give you and that sucks because a huge part of enjoying the combat in game is using that system.\n\nSo yes
hoursPlayed: as a VN it has problems.  You might even say crippling ones and I'd be hard pressed to argue diffrently.  But if you're looking for something to do for a few hours
voteText: you can't go wrong with this.  You can see and taste the potential here but that's all it is at the moment
helpfulPercent: potential.  Maybe future episodes will be better."
votesTotal: true

reviewText:
Sunrider: First arrival is an awesome game. As far as an anime game pretty much everything is there, cute girls ride space mechs in skin tight suits, with a bachelor who is probably not even 20 piloting a space ship with a huge gun sitting on top, yep typical anime game. Oh and did I mention that the voice acting, while sometimes repetitive is absolutely hilarious IMA FIRIN MAH LAZERS!!! As far as a turn based tatical rpg game everything is also there, a playing field with a limited per turn energy system that allows you to only do a certain number of actions per turn. There is also of course the variety of weapons you have to use on different ships/ mechs to deal more damage, as well as special abilities that can make or break the battle.

Now on to the bad side of the game. I understand this game IS STILL IN BETA, that being said there are some definent issues to work out. The animations are laggy, sometimes the animations will start right away, sometimes it will take about 5 seconds. The game has not crashed once, but the resolution while adjustable does not work! te only thing that will change is windowed/ full screen, so even when in a 16:9 resolution it still appears in window as 4:3, which is a bit unfortunate because it makes livestreaming it in a 16:9 resolution difficult. I am sure these things will be fixed in upcoming versions, and do not render the game unplayable! That being said, the game is still enjoyable, and definetely worth playing!

~jak113420
twitch.tv/jak113420

reviewText:
A very fun game. I would gladly have payed to play this and am looking forward to Liberation Day when it arrives.

The choices you have to make are hard and really make you think, however I would like to see more of these choices and maybe include short and long term effects (or at least more of them).

I also feel that the money system was a little flawed as there were not always enough chances to gain currency to upgrade the ships, or enough side missions.

Maybe adding in more optional side missions which open up as you progress through the story or due to the choices you make, this would help those players who get stuck in certain situations.

And lastly, I personally, would be intrested in the captain having a more active role in the combat. Maybe getting his own     Ryder. After all, the best bonds are born on the battlefield!

Overall, an amazing game with a good story and was very fun despite, and even due to it's quirks.

I'd rate it an 8/10!  Some issues but a must try!

reviewText:
I must admit that I generally don't play OELVNs because I find the writing to often be of a pretty poor quality, but the setting here caught my interest and so I decided to give it a shot.

I'm glad I did.

The game itself is a fairly standard grid-based SRPG. You expend energy by moving and attacking, and so have to weigh the risks of moving closer to allow for greater accuracy, but at the risk of not sinking enemy ships (and of course, the increased accuracy from moving your units closer also applies to the enemies too). There are multiple attack types in the game, each of them playing into the weaknesses of enemy units (though I must admit that I struggled to keep track of which attacks I should be using on the various enemy unit types).

Meanwhile, the story is presented as a fairly typical visual novel. The art looks really great, and the flight suits are wonderfully form-fitting... *ahem* The game is largely unvoiced however, so the only times you'll actually hear the characters speak is when attacking, or being attacked, during combat.

(As an aside, the music sounds great, but I noticed it can be pretty jarring when they have different songs playing according to whether it's the player's turn or the AI's turn, and that dramatic music you were listening to just suddenly cuts out so the other one can start up.)

reviewText:
Nice soundtrack, especially the voiced ones. Makes me wish the game will be available with japanese VAs too, really, this game would feel better with dual language dubs. Not that I complain with the english VAs. They've got it pretty decent. But hey, one can dream. Really. Wish this has the option to change the voiced audio played.

The one I'm having trouble with is about the unit selection method. Sometimes it's pretty tricky to select the correct unit when they're adjacent to each other. And really, one can miss target the unit they intend to attack or boost, because sometimes when you think you've selected the correct unit, you're actually select the unit in front of it (in matter of display order; which is usually the unit on the tile below it). Pretty frustrating.
Though, for now, you can undo the movement.

The other things, being beta, some stuff is missing, and the game will blatantly tells you that some animation is not found where it's expected, some graphics not found, etc. Which brings me to another thing about notification.
Can it be more visible? I mean, the text is just normal 12pt-ish font, which is easy not to be read.
Both because of it's size and the time it's on the screen, pretty quick to dissapear.

Oh and, being the customization and upgrades on the vessels are many, better ingame monetary system would help.

reviewText: This game took me by suprise, despite it having the visual novel aspect that I hear everyone and their mothers complain about (though that could just be me being an anime freak) I friggin' loved this game. This game took risks (which I like) like the visual novel, the turn based space combat, and the fact the story is reliant on being a trilogy whether or not the first entry works, yet this game went through the stratosphere at FTL and I don't think it's stopping. I loved the looks of the mechs and ship which had a lot more detail on them than I thought they were going in, and though I would have liked some FMV sequences during combat and story driven cutscenes" than images changing and beam effects swiping across the screen (though it made the death of one of the games villians hillarious

reviewText:
Excellent game, not to mention the fact it is free to play. I have long been a Visual Novel player, and while I have found several bugs that slow down the gameplay, they are minor at best. The story is interesting, and the cast fun. While the game is mainly a single path, there are some choices to add interactivity and the backstory is quite interesting at times.

Best of all, with the story, is the art, and most importantly the music. Some of the best music I have ever heard in a VN. Worth playing just for the music alone; at least in my opinion.

Would recommend Sunrider: First Arrival to any visual novel and Turn-Based game lover. Until the next adventure!

reviewText:
I'm a long time visual novel fanatic and I say, Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius is a MUST try for me. It doesn't have the character graphics that I totally love but the art is very nice. The designers have also found a way to make the animations interesting. The battle scenes are also good. The story focuses on how you, the captain, will save the galaxy while wooing your comrades. The game also includes a special setting that if you only like the visual novel part, the battle scences can be set to a point where you can't lose and if you love strategy/tactical games that much then you can change it to where enemies can only be beaten through a certain strategy. The heroines of the game have their own personality. The game also has good soundtracks. (if you love anime themes then you'll love it)

Pros:
1. It's a Free to Play game, so there's no hurt in trying.
2. The game has a great story and rumors say that it has a part 2.
3. Your decision largely affects the story proegression. (I'm sorry, I don't want to spoil anyone so I can't give examples.)

Cons:
1. The games has only a few soundtracks so every battle scenes, you'll be listening to the same track over and over again.

2. The attack types (LASER, KINETIC, PULSE, MISSILE, MELEE) in the battle part are a bit confusing at first but you'll get the hang of it.

Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius is an interesting visual novel with a mix of humor, space battle, and drama. The storyline itself covers up to its lack in graphics. If you're a visual novel fan, you have to try this!
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I'm not a fan of visual novel games, but I made an exception for Sunrider due to its inclusion of a turn based battle system (and because it was free) and was not dissapointed.  The story is actually quite good, and I found myself quite engaged by the characters.  It's all delightfully cliche, but well told.  The battle system is also fun and had plenty of options, however the game really should encourage players to start on Ensign difficulty rather than Captain, which would be considered the Very Hard" difficulty in most other games
date: and only for those already familiar with the game's concepts.\n\nFor a free game it's far more than I expected
recommended: and a great advertisement for the third installment."

reviewText:
(This is a combined review for both Sunrider: First Arrival and Mask of Arcadius.)

From my experience, Sunrider is an amazing visual novel/strategy game with an immersive, emotional story, world, and characters. The gameplay is a lovely grid-based strategy format, with a command points system for special attacks and abilities as well as a decent variety of special abilities and weapons per unit. Additionally, each unit can be upgraded quite a bit through the Sunrider's R&D section. On the standard difficulty, the combat isn't too difficult once you grasp the concepts of the game, however, there is a mode to essentially make each battle impossible to lose if you just want to experience the story.

On that note, the story is where this game truly shines. It has all the corny, cheesy scenes you might expect from a typical slice-of-life visual novel or anime, while doing so in such a way that it doesn't ruin the atmosphere that the game builds. Alongside those, there are rather intense, dramatic scenes and character development that serve only to add to the Sunrider experience. While there are no defined routes in this game (Only a positive/negative karma system depending on how much you care about your crew), the story and subtle romance vibes are still incredible. The voice acting is also amazingly good considering the size of the company that made Sunrider.

Most of the music, although well-planned and suitable for each scene, is standard royalty-free music you will likely have heard somewhere else. (One notable example being a royalty-free track used as the one of the space themes in Kerbal Space Program.) The next game is expected to have a completely original soundtrack.

Did I mention that Sunrider: First Arrival and Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius are both free? I would highly recommend this game/visual novel to anybody that enjoys both a good visual novel and strategy game.

As a side note, the next title in the core Sunrider series is now available on Steam; Sunrider: Liberation Day.

reviewText:
Excellent, free game which everyone ought to try out.

Combat is pretty unforgiving, which makes this feel less like a traditional turn-based tactics game ala XCOM and more like a board game. The utter lack of tutorialization does come up as a weak point, as do the semi-mandatory combat animations. These problems should be easily resolved with patching or in the sequels.

Characters are archetypal for the most part, but the plot is interesting. Takes a fairly cliched cast and story and instead of telling it straight or cynically deconstructing it, it uses these elements to create something original and worthwhile.

I was reminded a lot of Mouretsu Pirates with the way this game handled galactic intrigue and conflict, and if you liked that then you'll probably like this.

Looking forward to the sequels, hope developer Love in Space sticks around for more than just this series as well.

Still hopefully this game improves cause I would like to see the conclusion.

reviewText:
My thoughts, after around 7 hours in.

things i liked:
-worldbuilding: conversations fill in details of the current happenings, and of a rich history of space planets and civilizations.
-plot: not unbelievable stuff happen.
-art: didn't think it was great at first. after getting to know the characters, i think the art kinda complements their character traits.
-characters: characters have different personalities. it is interesting how one of them reminds me of a woman from real life. voice acting is ok. asaga's battle lines are hilarious.
-vn: it has moral choices, and some choices have real consequences on plot. for example, if I saved a group of people, would that have positive or negative long term effects on the overall war?
-turn based strategy: I enjoyed the Fire emblem and FFT games. This game is similar but has less movement, but you still have to make the right movements to use the right attacks on the right enemies in order to win. for example, there is a very useful aoe spell that costs a lot of points that are earned after battle, so I like to save points just to use the aoe spell on a bunch of high hp ships.
-rpg: your ship/robots are the chars whose stats you change. you use $ earned from battle to allocate strengths of the various attacks and defenses of the vessels.
-difficulty: just about right. later, battles get harder, and early battles might take some re-dos to guage enemy strength, but there is no char permadeath. there is also a very useful autosave function, for those misclicks.

meh:
-only female crew so far. If you're looking for males, there is only the MC, whose personality you build through the choices you make. so you can't really get to know a male crew member, as far as I know. There are generic male antagonists. The female crew aren't horribly written, but characters do try to appease those interested in relations with females.
-misclicks: clicking too much to try to skip battle animations can cause units to move after attacking, expending their energy points. can force you to start from the closest autosave, or restart the battle.

-no aliens or romancable space whales

current conclusion: I feel like i should give monies for this game, given how much I like it.

~~

so 20+ hours in or so, i've finally beaten the last three levels. third to last level (survive 6 turns) was difficult. I tried to wait it out with just two alliance ships, and played for 3 hours before lasting through 6 turns with just the sunrider at low hp. finished the level -1000 $ and -1000 command points, and it cost me a lot of time too; I found i could not beat the second to last level; I was pummeled to death by missiles on the first enemy turn, as I had no alliance battleships to do enough damage. So i restarted the survive 6 turns level with 4 mining laser ships, and retuned kryska's ryder into double kinetics/turn and the sunrider to have 2200 hp, in addition to having two alliance ships, in order to wipe out most of the enemy on the first and second turns with two carefully placed vanguard cannons, before the enemy could focus-fire people to death. success in that level led to a large army for the final levels, resulting in a much more manageable whittling away of the 25k hp boss ship. saw the kickstarter backers in the credits. definitely would want to back another installment of this, if another kickstarter pops up. for now, I await the third part.

reviewText: For me it is caught between a 9 and a 10. This visual novel has a nice story. Interactive and free. I love how this game reminds me of other games with similiar use of tactics. Nonetheless I believe the BG, Characters, Voices, and Art did show amazing continuity with it. Although I admit there is some details but as far as I have seen. This game has a lot of good even great. Multiple endings some choices, and to be honest if you liked War of the Human Tanks, you will like this. Also if you played any of other recently available on Steam VNs as of late, you will find a nice mixture. This one actually kept me entertained and interested. Although I admit pork chops should die, seriously and that goblin midget with a mask needs to get kicked like a football. I'm loving the game. What I find amazing is that it is simple and yet it reminds of me many other sci-fi related games. This game has provided me much entertainment and I do recommend it. It's not high action paced but the animations and the voice acting is what sold me. How many have actually done that? I'm not talking about VA in the scenes although that would be a plus but cost, however when they fight you hear them. I found that through this game a nice gravity of choice between the reality of what you want to do and have to do. Personally the comical relief brought about through the characters in between also helps. Not always so doom and gloom but it shows that there is more on people's mind. The artwork is very decent, the ships animations on firing were nice, the dialogue seems to be great. Some scenes show emotion and even makes me want to hear their voice. It's this type of game I do like. It gives you more than enough but it's so close to perfect they tempt you. Even though the voice acting isn't done, and the scenes with dialogue could use some more action, I do believe this is a 9-10 out of 10 in my book. Well done!

reviewText:
I just want to start off by saying i cant wait for the final chapter thats coming in January. After finishing the first two chapters I can say with confidence that this is a simple yet very fun game that the developers deserve a round of applause for. Its not without flaws and by no means is it perfect but it delivers a story that is fun to play through, a combat system that is simple yet challenging, and an upgrade system that rewards you for making differing choices.

PROS:
-Good story fits the game very well and does what it needs to do
(not anything revolutionary, but hey that doesnt mean its bad)
-Suprisingly good art and animated sequences
-Simple yet challenging combat system
-Great soundtrack really outstanding guys
-R&D system I felt was very rewarding if you allocated money properly (upgrades arent meaningless)
-Story choices i expect will play a bigger role in the last chapter but there are some in the first two that effect things without taking enjoyment out of the game
-Save/load system simple which allows player to explore different options
-FREE!!!!

CONS:
-Everything I could put here is going to come along with the final chapter
-For Example: I want more game to play, wish choices impacted more, oh and also i want more game to play

To sum things up i was bummed when i finished the first two chapters because i really wanted to continue playing the game, (I played through it twice). The thing that shocks me about this game though is that its free while at the same time being better then so many other games on steam. Definitely check this game out worst case you dont like it and delete it, but the developers made a story they wanted to make and it shows. I truly applaud their hard work and can't wait to see more from them (please continue making games).

reviewText:
This is a great little Visual Novel, the game itself is rather hard to get to grips with at first, even on easy difficulty, and you may find yourself trying levels multiple times, or lowering the difficulty just for the story to see what happens next. The characters are all unique with their own backstories that aren't quite fully explored and are shrouded in mystery for the most part still, but this is mainly so that more of the Visual novels can be made for this series, and i would happily welcome more edditions, especially if they are free like this one.

Now for the cons, there are so little side quests, you wonder why it introduced it at the start in the first place. I took time out of going from new sector to sector revisitng old ones hoping to find a side quest but didnt find any and was really disappointed. Missles feel vastly over powered in this game, doing high damage to units and yes whilst they are limited, later in the game when facing vast amounts of foes, the last thing you want is to be bombarded by dozens of missles to your flag ship. I also felt like i didnt get enough time in this first installation to get to know some of the characters, having them for a few missions only, whilst others you want to see more of because of how great of a character they are but seem to be forgotten about.

Some skills are missing and they openly tell you about this, and upgrades for some units are non existant, but so it the large amount of spare cash to effectivly feel like a real difference has been made asside from more missle slots.

But some of the best things i like about this Visual novel is the story, the voice acting during battle makes you feel more immersed and in command. The commands are great but very VERY expensve on the command points, which can be extremely irritating trying to save up and decide when to use due to really needing them in the later levels. But the best attacking being the Vanguard Beam really feels like the end all of all weaponry. It gets its own unique mini cutscene and attacking animation, slicing through all foes like a knife through butter and i really wish there were more attacks like this, maybe 1 for each pilot on the ship . Either way i cant wait for the next installment, highly recommend.

EDIT: Looks like a day after my review, an update came out extending the story even more, so glad I dont have to wait long to continue it.

reviewText:
i liked this VN, i find most VN tedious but the combat mixed with the interaction with other characthers made this experience enjoyable.

the good
+story
Not the best, but i've seen way worse than this. Around the story you can make decisions, rarely a game makes me stop to think about the consequences of my choices.

+combat
turn based strategy, knowing when to advance, when to fire with a specific type of weapon and many other things is essencial. This game even have some sort of agro system (seen this kinda thing in army of two), basically if you cause substantial amount of damage with a specific unit in the next turn is very likely that the enemy AI will focus fire on that unit. This agro mechanic can be an advantage or disadvantage is up to the player to decide how to used it.

+soundtrack
Music is nice anime like quality and the sound effects aren't bad either.

+characters
Like the story, not the best but i've seen worse. Some caracters are based on anime stereotypes like:
Icari a.k.a tsundere ツンデレ
Chigara a.k.a dandere ダンデレ
Sola a.k.a kuudere クウデレ
Asaga a.k.a Genki Shoujo 元気少女
There may be more but that's all i know

+universe
Has some interesting details like history and technology.

the bad
-Difficulty
For beginners this game can kick your ♥♥♥ if you're not familiar with its combat mechanics, i think the Devs should add an training tutorial. Sometimes even when you're used to the mechanics the AI just keep spamming hordes of infinite missles and certain missions requires specific types of upgrades, which means that if you don't have the necessary upgrade you will likely lose.

-combat UI
The user interface during combat should be improved, i can't count the many times i tried to click in one place and ended up clicking what i wasn't supposed to.


Overalll
I'm impressed what a small team managed to do so far, I wish luck and fortune for the developers.


october 6 2014
mask of arcadius

the good
+story
I feel like that the story improved, i really enjoyed the darker tone of this part

+combat
Almost the same of the first part but now the player can buy alliance cruisers, union frigates, shield generator for the sunrider, etc...  New units appear to fight for you and against you.
Some missions can be challenging making you stay on your toes and sweat, but they are not impossible. However there are moments which it feels that the enemies have some sort  of OP advantage which ill cover later.

They added more side missions to this part ( i think 4) and all can be accomplished. Ex: Side mission B, C, D will not dissapear if side A is completed, unlike the first part of sunrider where you could only do one mission)

+soundtrack
They added some new musics that are very good

+characters
We ge to know the past of some characters and also see some character development.

+combat interface
They improved combat interface, is rare when you click in something that didn't wanted to and the game doesn't lag" anymore when there's a great quantity of units on screen



the bad
-Rocket spamming
Seriusly
date:
the enemies have way more rockets than you do per unit and just can keep spamming you all day. To make it worse enemies now have support ryders that can disable your flak defenses. So i would suggest the devs to balance this issue by: decrease capacity of missles of enemy units or increase capacity of missles of my units or remove/decrease the flak worn off mechanic (the more missles the enemy shot at you the les it becomes effective)

-Enemy carriers
I feel that they are a little OP specially because they can deploy support ryders (2 at once!)
recommended:
and once deployed they can instantly attack/take action. My suggestion: make carriers being able to only deploy one support ryder instead of 2 at once and have a "cooldown" where the unit deployed by the carrier has to wait 1 turn before being able to act and the carrier have to wait 1 turn to be able to deploy again

-upgrades
Upgrades still feel dissapointing because they only start to become usefull at high levels which can cost a ton of money
hoursPlayed:
seriusly when i hear upgrades i expect that the performance of my ships to become better in a notable way

Overall
Still impressed if this game

reviewText:
I am a backer so my review might be bias for the game. I feel that the devs had done a very good job considering the limited amount of resources they have.

The artwork is good and the story is decent. Animation is minimal, but then, aniamtion is expansive to produce. Combat is simple, but surprisingly engaging.

Your capital ship and ryder (mechs) are specialized in different areas and proper useage of them is essential for victory. For example, your capital ship has good long range weaponry against other capital ships and can provide a large defensive flak cover, so it is usually placed in the middle of your fleet. One of the ryder is very mobile and is very effective at taking out other ryders, but is fragile and have limited range, it can be used near the front lines, move out, take out a few enemy ryder and then retreating back to cover.

Defensively, units need to be positioned such that their shield and flak stack together to defend each other more effectively. Moving aggresively might net you a kill, but those out of position units will take much more damage.

For the offence, you have missiles, lasers and kinetic weapons which are countered by flak, shield and armor respectively. Analyzing the best way to get pass the enemy defences is an interesting puzzle. For example, the first turn might be used to disable the enemy capital ship shields and use long range lasers to kill the high damage but fragile missile frigate. 2nd turn with the shield respawned, move in closer and use kinetic weapons to take out the enemy ryder who has no armor. Lastly with the flak defense from the ryder gone, disable the capital ship's own flak and kill them with missiles.

Killing enemy units will grant you money which can then be use to upgrade your ship and ryder to make them more powerful and more suited to your play style.

The only problem I have is with the lack of tooltips and awkard controls. For example, when encountering a new type of enemy, there is no way for you to know what type of weapons it has before it fire them at you. When trying to click on another unit with an unit already selected, its easy to misclick and unintentionally move the aleady selected unit by mistake. (Cancel move is possible, but require quick reflects to click it before it disappear) However, since that saving in the middle of the conbat is possible, save often and this is only a minor annoyance.

reviewText:
Can´t wait for the next episode. While the story is surely something that you will only like if you are into sifi, the gameplay is one of the best I´ve ever seen in a visual novel. The battles are pretty chalenging on normal and you have to consider a lot of things like different weapon types (which are actually pretty different). For examples Laser are long range, accurate and are not affected as strongly by armor, but do lower dmg and can be blocked by shields (which can overlap, making formations important). Gns are close range, but pack a lot of damage. Missiles have good range, dmg and accuracy, but are limited in supply and can be shot down by flak (which again can overlap).

Torpedoes can take down major ships in one hit, but need to be bought by in-game currency, which is also used for upgrades. So you have to deside when to use them. Also you get command points, which are taken over from one mission to another and can be used for buffs or firing the vanguard cannon. Again, the descision when to use this can make or break a battle.

All in all you have to consider formations, weapon types, defense types, and buffs / debuffs (which are actually important, unlike in many other games).

The game also offers four different difficulty modes.

Only critic point I have is that the characters are quite cliche and many of the surprises" can be seen a mile away. Also they introduce optional secondary missions
date: which are exactly used once. But
hoursPlayed: a very good start to a series that has some room to develop story wise
voteText: but is already excellent gameplay wise. Also it´s free

reviewText:
I must say, I adore this game! It has given me something I have been looking for years and could never find, solely due to the fact that what I was looking for was a turn based strategy with ships, unique mechs, engaging battles and a Gundam style universe feel. The reasoning behind that was from playing a Gundam flash game on a website in my childhood. This game brought me that and so, so, SO much more!

Onto the game itself. I truly went into it not setting my expectations to high but was thoroughly impressed, not only by the battle sequences but also by the story and the choices. I find myself extremely immersed in the story at key points and have even grown attached to many of the characters. This game brings so much and more the visual novel genre and I feel others could learn a great deal from it.

The mechs themselves all have fairly unique weapons and abilities which can all be upgraded along with armor, max energy, health and various other things. Four weapon types including close range blade combat (My favorite~) Long range lasers, Mid range kinetic and the so powerful we had to make them limited missiles. If there's one thing I can take away it's the fact that my game can tend to lag if to many units are on the screen. I have no clue why considering my computer can run some other games that are way more intense but it's not a huge annoyance so this game still gets my 10/10 Sunrider warheads.

What more is there to really say,It's free try for yourself, you have nothing to lose but a little time. There are games much, much worse then this that cost actual money or have a shorter playtime and offer only brief enjoyment. Due to that added onto the fact that this game mixes strategy, ship and mech upgrading, a beautiful soundtrack and a enthralling story it's a must (As long as, you know... Have no issue with little to no animation like I do.) and I will be waiting with bated breath to see what may lie ahead in games to come.

I find myself extremely immersed in the story at key points and have even grown attached to many of the characters. This game brings so much and more the visual novel genre and I feel others could learn a great deal from it.

The mechs themselves all have fairly unique weapons and abilities which can all be upgraded along with armor, max energy, health and various other things. Four weapon types including close range blade combat (My favorite~) Long range lasers, Mid range kinetic and the so powerful we had to make them limited missiles. If there's one thing I can take away it's the fact that my game can tend to lag if to many units are on the screen. I have no clue why considering my computer can run some other games that are way more intense but it's not a huge annoyance so this game still gets my 10/10 Sunrider warheads.

What more is there to really say,It's free try for yourself, you have nothing to lose but a little time. There are games much, much worse then this that cost actual money or have a shorter playtime and offer only brief enjoyment. Due to that added onto the fact that this game mixes strategy, ship and mech upgrading, a beautiful soundtrack and a enthralling story it's a must (As long as, you know... Have no issue with little to no animation like I do.) and I will be waiting with bated breath to see what may lie ahead in games to come.

reviewText:
I just want to start off by saying i cant wait for the final chapter thats coming in January. After finishing the first two chapters I can say with confidence that this is a simple yet very fun game that the developers deserve a round of applause for. Its not without flaws and by no means is it perfect but it delivers a story that is fun to play through, a combat system that is simple yet challenging, and an upgrade system that rewards you for making differing choices.

PROS:
-Good story fits the game very well and does what it needs to do
(not anything revolutionary, but hey that doesnt mean its bad)
-Suprisingly good art and animated sequences
-Simple yet challenging combat system
-Great soundtrack really outstanding guys
-R&D system I felt was very rewarding if you allocated money properly (upgrades arent meaningless)
-Story choices i expect will play a bigger role in the last chapter but there are some in the first two that effect things without taking enjoyment out of the game
-Save/load system simple which allows player to explore different options
-FREE!!!!

CONS:
-Everything I could put here is going to come along with the final chapter
-For Example: I want more game to play, wish choices impacted more, oh and also i want more game to play

To sum things up i was bummed when i finished the first two chapters because i really wanted to continue playing the game, (I played through it twice). The thing that shocks me about this game though is that its free while at the same time being better then so many other games on steam. Definitely check this game out worst case you dont like it and delete it, but the developers made a story they wanted to make and it shows. I truly applaud their hard work and can't wait to see more from them (please continue making games).

reviewText:
TL:DR> This is a VISUAL NOVEL that happens to have some strategic battle included.  Keeping that in mind, this is one of (if not THE) best visual novels I've read/played.  Loved it.

Okay... where to begin?

First... I read one of the reviews that said this was beta.  There's one typo I caught... and yes, the battles in regular mode (and above) can be hard.  HARD.  But... it's a visual novel with a game inside it... you can set the difficulty downwards if you need to.  So... I can't really say it's unbalanced... it's balanced for being a nut-kickingly difficult fight.  Unless, you know... you don't want to work that hard and you choose to set it easier... in which case it ranges from much more friendly all the way down to why-do-we-even-have-battles-if-they're-that-easy?

So it's not unbalanced... there's a type I caught... and... um... yeah.  That's it.  If this is beta, sign me up!

Now... this is, first and formost, a visual novel... meaning READING!  You has to do it!  If you don't like reading narrative, you will hate this game.  If you think you can just skip to the good parts... you will still hate this game.

If you're actually willing to read every line of text (and this is a looooong game... I spent 20 hours on my first playthrough) then you will probably dig this as much as I did.

Characters are shallow... but not two-dimensional... they grow, they expand, they have REASONS for being who and what they are.  You get to know them... and you get to like them.  Investment in this story is easy and rewarding.

Also: I'M FIRIN' MAH LAZORS!

Still laugh everytime I hear that.  Sorry... where was I?

Oh, yes... story.

Is it predictable?  Yes.  Don't expect some Lanister twist here, but at the same time it's not Lost where you'll be wondering what the heck REALLY happened.  It's a good, fundamentally anime story... with girls in skintight suits and giant mecha... love interests from all directions (but not the cheesy, I'll just date you all" male fantasy wank you might expect to find after the relationships start peeking out from behind the curtains)... and it does all of these tropes and more justice.

Now for some reason
date: I got to play it for free.  I have NO idea what that's about
hoursPlayed: well... I can say I'd have happily paid for this in hindsight.  $5?  Absolutely.  $10?  Probably.  More than that?  Hmm... hard to say.  There's not a lot of branches here... and they usually loop back to the same place.  Most people won't find a reason to replay it.  But honestly... for a good evening's worth (or two) of anime fun?  It's good.  Really good.\n\nFinal rating: best VN I've read yet.  All teh thumbs up!"

reviewText:
Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius is both a Visual Novel and Tactical RPG set in a futuristic universe, although it can be just a Visual Novel if you want to.

The positive:
-  Story: The story begins as a group named PACT forces its influence over neutral planets, killing millions of innocents in the process. And so it happens that our protagonist must become the hero who will stop PACT little by little with just one ship. Sounds cliched at first but there are interesting twists along the way.

- Characters: Harem! All the girls have common anime personalities, like the tsundere, the super serious, the shy, the silent and misterious and so on and so forth. In spite of this fact, there is quite a lot of character development, specially towards the end.

- Choices: The choices you are forced to make in this game also contribute to give personality to the main protagonist, since you can be a save the universe at all costs" kind of guy or have a "we won't sacrifice innocents" attitude. I'm not sure the choices have a huge impact in the long run
date: but they definetly change battles and make the game more compelling.\n\n- Soundtrack: I must say that I wasn't impressed by the first tracks I got to hear when starting the game
recommended: but later on there sure is great music
hoursPlayed:
specially during crucial points of the story.

The not so great:

- Voice acting: hit and miss. Some are just too annoying. You only get to hear it during battles though.

- Difficulty: battles are VERY hard in this game. The developers said that it's hard for a reason
voteText: after all you are trying to save the universe with just one ship. There are hard games which feel rewarding

you won't miss anything.

The negative:

reviewText:
Tl;dr version: Can recommend. Has surprising depth from a F2P Visual Novel. I wasn't really expecting a shockingly passable Turn-based combat space-sim, so I'd almost give it a thumbs-up on that alone. Solid soundtrack, too

Longer version: In truth, the characters are predictable anime-waifu trope material. There's the one with boobs who wants your junk. The shy one, etc etc. They say the same 2 or 3 lines over and over again in the combat sequences and they essentially all have the same model, just with different-colored hair/outfit that matches their Gundam-wing-type ship. They do have their own personalities and motivations and decent depth to the character. Be nice to see another male character that isn't a pompous ♥♥♥-wad/scheming d-bag/not blatantly evil, though. The villains of the game are uninteresting to the extreme and seemed to follow a Do-it-Yourself Build-an-Evil-Empire coloring book from Wal-Mart. That'd be the game's biggest drawback.

That being said, the plot and combat for a Visual novel is good. The Waifu-stuff is there and if it really matters to to, you get to see a boob. Not bad for a free to play game. The game is still in the beta stages, so there are still bugs present, although I have not encountered anything gamebreaking. The harder difficulties are definitely a challenge, so that's a point in its favor as well

Looking forward to the final chapter

reviewText:
Sunrider is not the most original game you'll play -- it reminds me very much of a Nintendo DS game called Infinite Space -- but it has a lot of heart.

The turn-based combat takes place on a hex-based screen. It initially seemed a bit slow and tedious, but then I found out that you can speed up enemy animations by holding down the CTRL button.

This is not the greatest game I've ever played, but it's definitely one of the most enjoyable. In spite of myself, I really came to care a lot about the characters. They're anime stereotypes, one and all, but that didn't detract from the experience. The game managed to make them charming and likable.

To me, the biggest and most pleasant surprise was that the story was actually worth experiencing in itself, rather than being just an excuse to fight in space and ogle pretty women. The combat difficulty can be decreased at any time, and in fact, I'd recommend most players to do that so they can enjoy the story without getting frustrated by the combat, which poses a significant challenge, even at the medium Captain" level. You face strategic

reviewText:
I must congratulate the developers and publisher for this piece of art.

Aside that I am not a big fan of text novels, fan service, etc... I want to congratulate the writer(s) sincerely. The story behind this game is so well thought and put together that it has kept me playing this for hours, without wanting it to end. Seriously, my congratulations to the writer.

But I AM a big fan of Turn Base Strategy and Mechas, and what you have done with the models, scenarios and mechanics is simply amazing.

The third, but perhaps second most important plus of this game is its soundtrack... Any game with such fantastic music will be a hit for sure. From the Opening to the battle and suspense tracks, everything is beautifully polished.

I just have a single request/suggestion: To make the riders able to inflict melee damage on vessels. That would be awesome.

Keep it up, love in space, you have won a follower here.

TV

reviewText:
Summary: If you wanted Mass Effect to be a Tactics RPG and Animu as all ♥♥♥♥ then this is your game. Surprising level of depth, aside from not having all the episodes released (so incomplete in story/content but complete in terms of game mechanics), I can only nitpick and it's completely free (zero microtransactions, but the final chapter will cost money to anyone who did not back the kickstarter).

I wanted to try this game out because the thing I liked most about playing Mass Effect and Telltale's The Walking Dead was not the shooting or QTEs, but having a group of likeable characters you interact with, getting to know more about them through conversations and making difficult choices that can affect them for better or for worse. Not to deny that the white haired sniper chick wasn't also part of the reason why. :3c
I have to say, the plot was surprisingly good, and the especially ending was very memorable, the characters are likeable enough, the lore is fairly interesting. The choices are morally ambiguious and they did a good job at making me really think about what I wanted to do, though I can't tell how much of an impact they really have on the storyline. Though I do want to point out that the opening narration is a bit stupid. It isn't a big deal because it does not have much affect on the plot, but to say that humans have subjugated (their words, not mine) all alien in life in the galaxy, then saying that PACT is bad because they are conquering the other human planets is a bit hypocritical.
The combat is also surprisngly enjoyable, I'm not an expert of TRPGs so maybe it is not the best, but I felt it had enough depth to be enjoyable. The Mechs (Ryders) are very diverse, have unique mechanics and I wouldn't say any of them are useless even if their roles may overlap at times (support, anti-ship, anti-ryder), they all do their roles differently. The kinetic/energy/missile damage types make for interesting tactical choices; do I want to sit back safely with accurate but weak energy weapons? Or close in and rely on kinetic but eat plenty of shots I might have otherwise evaded? Do I shoot my devasting but limited use missiles towards the front line to reduce the interception chance, or target the flagship in the back with the knowledge that I will be using my missiles in an ineffiecent manner as the enemies they bypass will increase the chance of my enemy shooting down the missile salvo? Do I want to use a melee Ryder to ohko an enemy Ryder if it means giving my enemy a free attack by getting with their counter attack" range?
Also
date: having some attacks have multiple shots with their individual calculations to hit and armor/shield reduction being per shot made the difference between a rapid fire kinetic assault rifle and a single shot kinetic cannon important

reviewText:
To get the bad stuff out the way, the combat section of the game is horribly optimized, occasionally running into glitches (which is perfectly acceptable for a free Early Access, of course!), highly allergic to alt-tabbing, certainly far from balanced in most scenarios requiring one to be liberal in their application of the difficulty settings, and generally being slow all round.
There are also a few signs here and there of sub-par quality control.  Nothing deal-breaking, but simple repetitive things.  Like being able to hear the click of Asaga's VA releasing her PTT.
THAT SAID:

Those are two of my three only complaints.  I loved it.  The story is riveting and characters are fantastically loveable.  The soundtrack is wonderfully fitting.  And for such a simplistic and intuitive system, the combat mechanics are actually very complex and demanding of some thought.  I found myself actually having to plan out my expenditures for research and fleet composition in order to be able to best tackle the enemy using my preferred strategy.  The animations, while simplistic, are certainly immersive.  The AI can occasionally even pull out some interesting tactics that force me out of my usual strategy.  It was certainly the most entertaining 25 hours I've spent in a game in the past 6 months at least.
In fact, I could even say I had FUN.  Which is a refreshing experience these days.

And of course, the most important part of any game, the real keystone of any enjoyable gaming experience: Were there any moments that truly stood out, that will jump to the forefront of my memory any time I think of the game, ones which instill in me a sense of excitement and desire to jump right back into the game?

This is my command: prepare to fire the Vanguard cannon!  Vanguards
date: fire!"\n\nNow for my third and final complaint.  The cliffhanger has left me wanting more!  The itch left me by this game cannot be scratched by anything else on the market!"

reviewText:
Definitely a real gem here.

First let's get the major point out of the way. It's free. So you've got nothing to lose by trying it! But be warned, it's still not complete" as there's still one more chapter to come out. Think of it as the A New Hope and the Empire Strikes Back.

But onto the actual meat and potatoes now...

If I had to describe Sunrider
date: I'd say that it'd be what you get if Valkyria Chronicles
hoursPlayed: X-COM and Ah! My Goddess got SUPER drunk one night and did some things they will probably never speak of to each other. Well
voteText: their loss is our gain. Sunrider is an epic space opera about you Kayto "Captain" Shields trying to defeat an evil empire that has been blasting people up for no good reason. You're given a newly commissioned sweet ♥♥♥ battlestar called the Sunrider (which is pretty much an expy for the Space Battleship Yamato) which you can take into combat and a bunch of insanely giant mecha that you gradually fill up your hangar with. Of course
helpfulPercent: this being a visual novel in the best anime style all the mecha pilots are waifus. You could pretty much list off exactly who you'll be getting
votesHelpful: the hyper-kinetic one
votesTotal: the quiet one
votesFunny: the shy one
commentsCount: the cold badass that is sensitive on the inside and the one you have history with. While this could have been used as a set up for simply some massive amounts of T&A (and there is some) the devs actually put together a great story with these characters. By the end of it
column16: you'll have saved a few planets
column17: gone to a creepy alien graveyard
column18: helped out some local miners
column19: crashed a wedding and (of course) gone on shore leave which fans of anime will immediately recognize as "The Beach Episode". Sure some of this might seems like TVTropes fodder
column20: but they manage to stich it together into a great narrative
column21: complete with drama
column22: romance and a helpful smacking of comedy. But in addition to the cutesy covering
column23: this game explores some fairly dark themes like collateral damage
column24: betrayal and slavery. All of these are explored in the Visual Novel side of the gameplay where you can wander around your ship and talk to your crew.\n\nWhile the visual novel style of gameplay is satisfying
column25: the meat of the game is in the combat. Here
column26: the turn based style of X-COM is fully utilized. You get a hex grid with the baddies on one side and your forces on the other. Each unit has a set number of "Energy" that is used up when it does things like activate special abilities
column27: move and fire weapons. The Sunrider is often the anchor of the formation and has an array of extremely powerful weapons like lasers (weak but accurate)
column28: kinetic cannons (powerful but inaccurate) and missiles (powerful and accurate but limited salvoes and can be shot down). There are also a couple of special abilities that you can use like the wave motion gun
column29: resurrection of an ally and so forth. Backing you up are the numerous Ryders that are essentially fighter jets to your carrier. But
column31: no one wants to see boring old space fighters
column32: and the Ryders are all special mecha. Each Ryder (piloted by one of the aforementioned waifus) has a specific role
column33: strengths and weaknesses. The Black Jack
column35: is a general purpose combat unit designed to soak up and dish out damage while the Seraphim is delicate but can wreck enemy units from long range with a sniper cannon and the Paladin is a mighty glacier. As you can imagine
column36: it takes all your forces working together in order to pull out a victory as you are usually outnumbered. It's elegant and fun
column37: especially those times when you pull off that one low percentage shot to save your girls. Fortunately
column38: even if you mess up a bit
column39: anyone that gets to zero HP (besides YOU of course) pulls back to the carrier and will be available for the next battle. The only annoying bits are some of the combat exclamations which get a little tedious after a while.\n\nIn another nod towards the X-COM and Valkyria Chronicles style
column40: the spoils of victory give you resources which you can use to upgrade your forces such as by increasing their amount of energy
column42: making your weapons more powerful and even purchasing some backup. You'll quickly find that there's no way that you'll be able to afford all the upgrades so it becomes a careful balancing act as to where you'll spend your money especially as there's no way to "farm" resources. I would have appreciated a way to get some additionaly cash as currently there is no way to get more than partially up the tech tree for any one unit without nerfing everyone else. Still
column43: if you're wise about your choices and concentrate on each Ryder's strengths
column44: you'll get a formidable fighting machine in the end.\n\nAll in all
column45: Sunrider is a great game and needs to get a sequel pronto. I'm dying to know how all this madness ends. Love In Space is yet to release the final chapter of the game but you can bet that I'm going to be first in line to get my hands on it!\n"

Easy game on captain(normal) once you know what to buy.

Key pointers for the game:
Sunrider should have 7/5/4 on kinetic(minimum) shield and +1 range 125energy(for 5 flak rounds)
Chigara and claude should have a a range of 2 (+5 shield power is optional)
Sola should have +7atk 130 energy and 65%kinetic energy usage(~$300 cheaper) acc is optional but recomended
2allience cruiser are very important
use all guard to fight against overwhelming missles and lasers
chigara has repair boosters that adds 200hp more
complete all missions

these are the most basic set up and pointers i use when i play on captain mode. have fun

reviewText:
This review will be mainly comparing the game with its spin-off Sunrider Academy. I first bought that game and noticed all the in-game references to this game (but also missed a lot). Anyway, I got interested and downloaded. This game is so good that it wiped out my disappointment with Sunrider Academy. I even didn’t pay full price for that one. But if it pays the salary of the devs so they can make games like this, I totally can live with it.
The characters were clearly made for this novel. They  felt out of place in Academy. I think that’s because  in Academy they are children who act like adults and here they are adults who (sometimes) act like children. That also explains why they are funny from the start where in academy they could be annoying (Chigara’s bakery, Ava’s uptightness though well explained, Sola’s solitude) You also should check out in the bonus the reaction of the ladies to the polls. Very funny
The main choice in the game is a classic big one. Does the goal justify the means. Kudos for not making it an easy one. It kept me pondering for a while over some what ifs in history (20th century of course).
The battle parts are challenging and not in my mind repetitive like the managing in Academy (Although I accepted that as part of the high school experience).
Now I’m hooked and I even haven’t finished the game once.

The game has a phenomenal story, really nice tactics, and amazing soundtrack; and it's all for FREE! :D

The game should keep you engaged as much time as it did me (around 19 hours), and that's with only one run through; these guys will be developing the story for free down the line.

reviewText:
The feeling I get from this game is that it could still be greatly improved.

Mind, I started the game and was compelled to finish it in one sitting (being frustrated at difficult/tricky missions, much as the numbers worked against me). Throughout that, I’ve crashed the game countless times (mostly through a save/load prompt causing it to look for a missing animation file, or skipping battle scenes and somehow causing it to crash from there). That said, the whole thing could still be improved, from the interface, to the fluidity of the system, to the behavior of the AI — pretty much everything can still take a touching up.

Regardless, it was and is a pretty good game. I enjoyed it and the challenge it gave - Captain: Way the game is meant to be played; much harder than I thought it’d be for the ‘suggested’ setting - and would invite you to try it out. The story is nothing special, but it’s definitely good for what it is.

This has a lot of potential!

reviewText: If you're going to play this game, you're either really into visual novels, or really into tactical rpg's, and the game actually handles both competently. There are plenty of flaws here that would break a commercial game, but for a free game, it's strengths outweigh it's frustrations. Yes, it's a freeware game, by the way. No tricks.\n\nSo what have we got in the VN side? A harem story that paints it's characters in broad strokes, doesn't branch out much in terms of individual heroines, has pretty generic and partially unfinished looking visuals (some of the menu's repurpose the concept art scetches) and that really doesn't stray far from the tropes of a regular band of misfits rises up against evil" story. However

reviewText:
Sunrider is a free-to-play visual novel/scfi hex based strategy game. The game has a wide range of dificulties to choose from. The default dificulty is quite chalenging and rewarding. The game isn't finished at the time of this review.
Sunrider offers a wide range of choices that affect what kind of mission you will face and how your ships a positioned.
The game is set in a cold war between the reds and the the republic union. The protagonist is from a neutral planet that is atacked by the reds and from there is given to the player moral choices between sabotaging the reds and saving people from pirates and human traffickers. Until now choices dont seem to have impact in the overall story except the last one from the mask of arcadius chapter.
Side missions in the game are few and far between, because of that money is scarce in the default dificulty so upgrading your ship is dificult. I had problems because the game doesn´t explain fully how the combat works, for example damaging a ship also reduces the armor, i like the detail but it took me a while to get it because the a game has a reasonable number of stasts and it would be helpfull if they had something explaining besides the hints in the dialogue in the initial battles.
I recomend the game because it has a good story with some funny moments and the combat is quite challenging and enjoyable.

Great game if you like visual novels with a tactical round-based combat system and sci-fi genre  (like I do^^).
The story is pretty deep and interesting, lots of emotion and sometimes hard decisions. The characters are really well made, both in art style and in personality and the artwork in general is fantastic. The combat system is well balanced and the fights make a lot of fun.

Still hoping for romancable space whales... or a harem ending ;)

reviewText:
The characters, while all conforming to the typical anime stereotypes (the genki girl, the shy one, the tsundere, the perv with questionable morals, the silent and mysterious one, the business-y one), still work work really well off of each otherr. The art is superb, and the dialogue can be really entertaining at times.

The story's unique and well thought-out, with valid questions being asked of the player. What should be sacrificed in the name of a greater victory? Do the ends justify the means to stop a horrible evil?

Plus, there might be space whales, and that's a BIG plus from me. Why? Because space whales are awesome.

----------------------------------

This game, however, is not without its flaws:

The combat, unfortunately, is one of my least favorite aspects of the game (which is bad, because that's a huge part of the game). I've played (and beaten) the Advance Wars games, so I'm not a newbie to turn-based tactical RPGs, but there's some severe imbalance in the combat. The developers stated that this is intentional, as you're supposed to be a lone pilot fighting off a heavily-armed empire; however, I've had attacks that should have a 100% chance of hitting the opponent miss, and I've had stealthed characters still get attacked while stealthed. Granted, this is still a game being patched, so these might be fixed soon.

I'm also not too fond of the combat mechanics as a whole. Most of your turns will involve scanning through each character, highlighting each of their abilites, and seeing which will have a better chance of hitting the enemy you're trying to attack (when the game even bothers to show the correct hit percentage). I've never seen a game successfully pull off having every attack have a different (seemingly random) chance of hitting the opponent and not have it be aggravating. A game like this should be based on skill, not chance.

Could you also give us some indication of the enemy's attack range as well? Please? I don't particularly like thinking I'm doing really well, then getting absolutely nuked by a bombardment of kinetic fire because I had no idea I was close enough to be hit.

Also, the missles are a huge source of headaches. I decided to do an experiment, and saved right before I fired a rocket so I could test something. As I soon found, some of the times, all of the rockets were intercepted by flak (the game's only way of deflecting 100% accuracy rockets), and sometimes NONE of them were. So, once again, the game's combat comes down to chance and luck. Good luck having Icari survive being on the front lines for more than one turn before being nuked to oblivion!

The upgrades for ships are far too small and too pricey to make any noticable difference. Money runs out far too quickly for each upgrade, and as such, you're going to have two or three of your Ryders being underdeveloped if you want your others to be remotely competent.

The game has a system for command points"

reviewText:
This is simply the best Original English language visual novel made as of yet. The characters are likable, the story is a proper story with actual conflict and character development. The combat system is good, though the animations can get a bit tedious at times. You can turn the fights into visual novel mode if combat isn't your thing... The biggest issue with visual novel mode is that, well, you still have to do the fights. I also wish that your choices had more impact on the actual game. Although the game seemed to care about which choices I made in First Arrival, I don't think they really had too much of an impact on the story. But, maybe your choices in this game will impact the next a little bit more.

The people at Love in Space are brilliant, and I can't wait for the next chapter to come out! I'm sure that if you seemed interested enough to read this review, you will absolutely adore this game, just as I did.

Also, thanks to Sekai Project, who published this game on Steam... Look forward to the games they are going to be releasing too! If you liked Sunrider, I'm sure you'll like the other Visual Novels coming up.

By the way, I noticed the Fault reference in game... Nice to see that AID has seemingly managed to make a series that could span however far into the future Sunrider is set!

Plus, there might be space whales, and that's a BIG plus from me. Why? Because space whales are awesome.

----------------------------------

This game, however, is not without its flaws:

The combat, unfortunately, is one of my least favorite aspects of the game (which is bad, because that's a huge part of the game). I've played (and beaten) the Advance Wars games, so I'm not a newbie to turn-based tactical RPGs, but there's some severe imbalance in the combat. The developers stated that this is intentional, as you're supposed to be a lone pilot fighting off a heavily-armed empire; however, I've had attacks that should have a 100% chance of hitting the opponent miss, and I've had stealthed characters still get attacked while stealthed. I'm also not too fond of the combat mechanics as a whole. Most of your turns will involve scanning through each character, highlighting each of their abilites, and seeing which will have a better chance of hitting the enemy you're trying to attack (when the game even bothers to show the correct hit percentage). I've never seen a game successfully pull off having every attack have a different (seemingly random) chance of hitting the opponent and not have it be aggravating. Also, the missles are a huge source of headaches. I decided to do an experiment, and saved right before I fired a rocket so I could test something. As I soon found, some of the times, all of the rockets were intercepted by flak (the game's only way of deflecting 100% accuracy rockets), and sometimes NONE of them were. So, once again, the game's combat comes down to chance and luck. Good luck having Icari survive being on the front lines for more than one turn before being nuked to oblivion!

The upgrades for ships are far too small and too pricey to make any noticable difference. Money runs out far too quickly for each upgrade, and as such, you're going to have two or three of your Ryders being underdeveloped if you want your others to be remotely competent.

reviewText:
Since Sunrider's original release, things have changed, the combat system grew more complicated and challenging, and the story stopped being developed as well as it had been. I, like many of the other kickstarter backers for this game, didn't back this game for it's combat systems, though they were interesting; I backed the game for it's promise of a sweeping space opera, what we have received is not that. The story is barely there (try playing with dev cheats on and skip the battles, the story takes just a fraction of the normal time) the characters feel like cardboard cut outs and the combat is so clunky and boring it just saps all enthusiasm for the rest of the game. I can no longer recommend this game in this state or any state that follows this path, only a rewrite of the game from the end of part one could possibly save it now.






Original, now out of date review.

Don't let my complete lack of gameplay time fool you, as a Kickstarter backer for Sunrider I've been playing various versions of Sunrider since the first demo last year. The current beta version of the game has around 10 hours worth of content split between turn based combat and visual novel sections. The Visual Novel sections work as expected of a typical Japanese VN with the occasional choices that can change outcomes or allow you to learn more about your enemies or the lore. The Turn based combat sections put you in command of the Sunrider and various Ryders (big robots). Each Ryder has it's own weapons and abilities and while learning what each one does can be a pain (the lack of tooltips is being worked on) once you've mastered them you'll be a force to be reckoned with. The turn based combat also includes voice acting by professional and amatuer voice actors and actresses. Combat difficulty is still being worked on but at the moment ranges from super easy in the form of Visual Novel" difficulty to the very difficult "Hard" difficulty. I must also make note of the amazing soundtrack which makes each and every moment of the game feel amazing.

Note: Keep in mind that the game is still in a beta state and could still include bugs.

For the Sensitive Gamer: Sunrider includes some brief sexual content and nudity
