reviewText:
Down to the letter, this was by far the most worthwhile $0.00 I ever spent! it was an incredibly fun joyride, filled with loveable anime characters and awesome giant battle robots! I am a huge fan of anime and stuff, but this was taking it to a whole new level....still, for the sake of this review, I shall maintain enough professionalism to make a Pro-Con bit. ok, here goes.

Pros:
Amazing ships an' guns an'stuff. LOTSA DAKKA DAKKA!!!!
Realistic-yet-dreamable cast. they all have as much depth and background as you care to look into.
The main protagonist is so relatable, it felt like I was in his position, saying and doing almost everything he did in his place.
The story was very well-done.
It has challenge, which, in my opinion, is a Pro. I enjoy fair tests of my strategic skill.
It has choices, which I adore the ability to fine-tune the path that the story takes.
It is NOT pay-to-win. hell, there IS NO microtransaction system at all! it's JUST a game, no strings attached!
It's free to play, free to download, and runs well.

Cons:
The animations sucked. the characters and ryders/ships were all 2-d drawings that had limited motion and low depth. to be fair, it doesn't really matter so much, but as a part-time animator, It nags at me.
They tried to over-adulterise certain parts. I don't mind a little bit of spice now and then, especially considering that it's an anime thing, so you kinda expect that, but there is one instance of nudity, as well as a scene on the beach where.....I'll let the imagination do the talking on that one. it's not THAT bad, except for that one instance of unnecessary nudity.
For some people, this would be a con, but personally I don't mind the limited voice-acting. The fact that they have limited voice acting leaves more for the imagination to do, which is an easily-accomplished boon for me at least.
Almost no sidequests. NEEDS MORE!!!
Needs to be longer. I beat this game after about 12 hrs. still, I have yet to try the high-difficulty levels. I personally would've loved to see a longer story however.
Lil' bit laggy in combat for some reason. doesn't matter, considering that it's a TBS, but still. it could be annoying for some people.

End statement:
I freakin' LOVED this game. I can't wait for them to make the next one in the series. (Also, I'm totally in favour of Claude! <3 ) erm....*ahem* anyways, 'twas a great game, I hope the reader of this review enjoys it as much as I have, and I hope that Love in Space" finishes the next installment in the series soon!

PS: have a nice day

reviewText:
Cliche anime girls everywhere can be annoying, but if you're purely interested in the tactics, you can easily skim read/ skip past the terrible dialogue and get to the space battles. While there are lower difficulty levels, the default setting is quite brutal and will punish illogical investments and particularly faulty tactics. It plays a lot like a Super Robot Wars game, although there is not much animation and there are fewer, stronger enemies. The graphics are sufficient to get the job done though and the latest update now helpfully shows enemy flak and shield zones on the grid.

The game doesn't really explain the enemy AI, flak and shield coverage as you go along, so it's worth heading to the wiki for a combat overview as otherwise missiles and lasers can seem hopelessly unfair.  Also be aware that rockets purchased from the mining guild are 1 use only weapons, unlike hired extra ships which stay with your fleet until destroyed.

The main plus point: it's a completely free space tactics game.

reviewText:
This JRPG is a doujin (non-japanese made) which made me skeptical at first, but since it was free i ended up trying it.
I've really enjoyed the game, especially the gameplay. The story seems childish at the start, however precisely ecause of that it really shows how hard things are for the MC (main Character) as you progress through the story. The gameplay could be considered a formality due to how the story is => they included a visual novel mode" difficulty for those who are only interested in story - impossible to lose and also impossible difficulties for masochists

Story - 7/10 strong first few hours eased my way into the story. Too many cliches throughout the story for my liking tho and a very strong story towards the end. However it is definatly parts 1 and 2 out of 3 in this trilogy. It has set up a really good stage for the 3rd part which could be amazing. honestly the only shortcoming from my point of view was that at times the MC seemed slightly dumb. Though i think it wouldnt bother most people.

Characters 8/10 Some of the characters are carbon copies of what you'd expect
date: there is a "tsudere-chan" and so on. At first it bothered me
recommended: but later on in the story when things got more complicated some brilliant characters made appearances. especially the pirates are executed brilliantly. all in all i have to say the mental arc was exellent thanks for that!\n\nGameplay 9/10 I loved the gameplay. Partly because i felt nostalgic since it resembled other games i've played. It is a turn-based strategy game which punishes you mercilessly (if you make the difficulty sadistic). Its been a long time since i've had to go all out

It made it really feel like a small group of people fed their soul into this

reviewText:
Alright. The story is nice, the characters have actual dimensions and interact with each other, and it can be a very human portrayal.

But! And there is a but, the combat can be described as 'maddening'. I got to a late-game section, admittedly with screwups, and hit a stone wall even on Normal. Some of the side missions are past completing in terms of ability, and even further than that you won't know until about twenty minutes into a couple that since you didn't knock out A mech/ship so quickly you wind up not being able to do a damn thing about it when you lose. Also? A strategy to warp should involve the fall-back warp BACK. A strategy they teach in-game is a sure-fire way to get your ship down to half health or less in a single turn.

The visual novel? Written well. A few mistakes here and there, but interesting. The combat? Anything above Ensign (mid-level, basically) you may as well go grab a brick and start smacking yourself in the head with it.

Also? Was kinda hoping there to actually BE romance. Not just pining. Ending's a bit abrupt as well.

reviewText:
Couple Quick Thoughts . . .

I've given this game several playthroughs on various difficulties.  Just a few things . . .

Pros)
1.  Excellent game overall.  Can be enjoyed as a visual novel or strategy depending on your preference.
2.  Good story, great music.

Cons)
1.  Upgrade costs . . . even at lower levels, upgrades have to be chosen carefully.  Potential for tweaking in future instalments/chapters.
2.  Spacewhale Mode:  You guys really wanted it to be unbeatable . . . if the above problem is addressed, then this sorts itself out.

Overall:  8.9

reviewText: The main problem with this game is that it's riddled with bugs that many times prevent you from continuing. reviewText:
Review outdated and based on Act 1 exclusively:

There's a decent and enjoyable game in here, but the strategy RPG half doesn't run well, and this is very curious for a visual novel not to run well on most computers.

I have a pretty high-end gaming rig and it still stuttered significantly. After sharing it with someone with a more average rig, they could barely run the game. You can always read it in Novel Mode, but it's not particularly long or worthwhile in that case. Characters are pretty archetypal and the general plot, aside from the diplomat rescue, isn't much to write home about right now.

The strategy gameplay is somewhat flawed and especially punishing, and late-game is especially brutal with insistence on missile spam that can wipe out most of your team quickly from most ranges. This is especially frustrating in levels requiring you to advance to the opposite side of the map as moving and attack draws from the same energy pool. It does adequately capture the sense of opposing an overwhelming force, but luck-based factors of missing are frequent and necessitate time-consuming save stating and reloading. It's challenging if this is up your boat, but it can easily frustrate in combination with the game engine's inefficiency.

There are definitely things I like a lot about this, mostly the attention paid to lore and background, and this is definitely a promising enough start to a potential series. The strategy RPG component must be optimized, however, as it is very difficult to enjoy at this point. Much of the story is spent setting up characters and the setting in general, and there is a lot of room to grow and make later episodes much more worthwhile. As a standalone game for now, there's much to be desired.

It is free, though. If you have a high-end rig, the strategy RPG should run good enough for you to enjoy. Otherwise, you should look elsewhere.

reviewText:
Gameplay
The gameplay is okay, but suffers from some glaring problems. There is no way to get more detailed breakdown on the enemy ships that I could find. The shield system seems to be buggy - a unit sitting in the middle of two shields takes about 1/3 the damage, at best, that it should from lasers. The flak system is never explained. It shoots down missles, but it's unclear how exactly this calculation works so you just have to guess if the relatively expensive flak upgrades are worth it. Worse yet, later stages feature units that spam missles at you and your flak gets less effective as it shoots missiles down, and one missle volley can half kill (or worse) your lighter units.

Balance
The balance needs some serious work in this game. Short-range weapons are largely useless, and this makes Phoenix garbage. The Phoenix has two weapons - Assault, and Melee. Assault and Pulse weapons have horrible accuracy beyond just a couple hexes, and are unable to damage anything with armor, shields, or speed: this is everything in the game. Melee is useless in most situations because being near ANY enemies on their turn means you die. The Phoenix has twice the evasion of any other unit, but even it can't reliably dodge things at its own engagement range. Kinetic has similar accuracy issues - it's almost impossible to hit anything beyond a few hexes, especially fast units - but at least it can do a lot of damage to armored units. Lasers are great until you get to later stages where half the enemy units have shields 1-2 hexes wide. As previously mentioned, overlapping shields are far more effective than math accounts for...for enemies. You do not get the same benefit.  Missiles are great, assuming you can overcome the enemy's flak, but are extremely limited in use so they're not a viable main weapon. Enemies don't suffer from this problem as they seem to carry up to 6 missiles each, and have much higher flak resistance.

Upgrade System
I'm giving this its own category because it's honestly the root of all the issues in the game. You are given extremely limited funds to upgrade your units with no way to get more outside of the 5 side missions (you can only do 4 of them). The upgrades get expensive very quick, and while you can sell upgrades you lose money in the process. Thanks to the strict funding limit and the increasingly inefficient upgrades you are completely shut out of a number of strategies. Turtling isn't viable after the first few stages due to the overwhelming enemy numbers, the prevalence of missiles and high cost of flak upgrades, and certain mission requirements. You can't focus on evasion because it costs more than you can get to get high enough evasion to survive. So you're forced into an offensive strategy where the upgrades are - for the most part - relatively cheap. Missiles aren't an option because you cannot possible get enough of them to win a stage. So you're forced to level Lasers on the two units that get them (Sunrider and Blackjack) and Kinetics on the rest. You'll also have to raise HP on your units eventually.

Sound
The voice acting is actually done quite well, which was a pleasant surprise. The music is nice, but gets repetitive after a while. Overall very impressive for a small developer.

Graphics
The women are pretty, the ships and ryders are well designed, and the backdrops are well done. No complaints here.

Story
The story is a strange beast. It has all the right elements, but it never drew me in and didn't really satisfy. Perhaps it relied too much on tropes, perhaps it's going to work better when it's complete - I can't really say what the issue here is.

Intimacy & H-Factor
There is a sad lack of intimant scenes in this VN. There are some very cute ones, don't get me wrong, but most of them fall short of satisfying because they're largely explained instead of shown. You almost never get to see the captain - an attractive, relatively fleshed out main character for a VN - interact with any of the crew. It's a huge missed opportunity. As such there is only one H scene in the entire game - a shower scene. The woman in this scene is very pretty but it's a single still frame and feels very out of place. It would almost have been better to not include it.

Overall
It's a good first attempt, but the game needs to deliver on its own promises. This review would have a completely different tone if the promised numerous side missions and lost technology existed in the game, or even if there was a way to engage in random battles to get money for upgrades. A strategy game should allow any strategy one can come up with, not shoehorn you into a single option. One need only look to Super Robot Wars to see how a game like this can work - SRW has limited missions and thus limited income, but it's balanced well enough that there is no useless attack, stat, or unit. Sunrider could learn a thing or two from the SRW series.

reviewText: A free VN that combines a space opera and a turn based strategy game, You play as a captain of a lone top of the line ship in your quest to fill your hangar with female mecha pilots. Sounds a little familiar? Galaxy Angel isn't too much different.  For a free game, it's not bad, it goes into some of the usual cliches, but otherwise manages to be entertaining. The combat isn't really explained to you but you'll pick it up quick enough, however it does seem a little wonky, your mechs aren't really able to fit their roles properly, and you'll just usually rely on your flagship to do any damage about 70% of the time.  The game is a little hard in that it takes you a llitle bit to actually find out what's effective, and focus on upgrading that while ignoring everything else, movement costs and certain upgrade prices probably need to be looked at.  Also the art is terrible. It's very bland and as far as character design goes uninspiring. For a game funded on kickstarter I'm pretty sure a better artist could have been obtained, Yes I understand there are a bunch of popular visual novels with less than stellar artwork, but they have more heart" to them. At least galaxy angel had some style going on

reviewText:
The greatest flaw with this game is that the soundtrack is too epic for the game......even if it is production-music (Mark Teichert among others) i must make this comment. It's suitable during gameplay segments but during dialogue it is too good for a game using static non-cinematic images and dialogue-segments. Frequent but effectively used short animations and different static-images would have made the epic orchestral score more suitable but also more dramatic as it would have lifted up the presentation and made it better and more dramatic in my opinion. The dignities between the score and VN-segments does not match imo, and little does it help when everything else is usually quiet without any voice-acting other than during gameplay segments. -_-  It put me in a lukewarm, damped enclosed atmosphere. A box.

Another thing is the lack of achievements wich strips the game from giving me any rewarding feeling after executing an effective battle and being a commander. The last flaw, wich i found a little bit embarrassing was that the galaxy-map is clearly a wannabe and copycat of Bioware's Mass Effect galaxy-map. Come on man......

Other than that, thrilling story and medium anime-visuals.

SCORE IF IT HAD BEEN DIFFERENT: 8/10
CURRENT SCORE: 6,8/10

CONCLUSION:
I will continue to play. Might contact the developer for future game-development ;)

RESULT:
Nominated for Best Visual Novel and Best Indie-Game*

*i love giving academy awards" ;)"

reviewText:
It's not a bad game, it's just not a good game. The fights are okay, though a little unfair at times (had a units get wiped out in opening volleys a few times).

Storywise, there were tidbits of backstorys that were interesting, but the characters felt rather generic. BBEG reveal wasn't surprising if you've seen Yugioh Zexal.

Art looks nice, but I can't see why they go around the ship in schoolgirl outfits...some would blame it on the genre, but given that the previous game revolves around an Academy (which I haven't played) it wouldn't surprise me to learn that they're assets lifted from that.

While it's an okay time sink, I don't think there was any great benefit of playing it. Something like Long Live the Queen is more frustrating but also satisfying.

Note for the designer: Consider a pre-rolling system for fights to reduce save scumming to get extra hits/damage.

reviewText:
Currently, the price is definitly right. Free. The story has potential, the gameplay is difficult, but customizable, but very linear. Only two or three significant choices are possible. There was an early option for side quests, but that only occured once when it truly is needed for the currency to buy upgrades as the game ramps up to massively difficult quickly.

Also the game is only playable for the first chapter right now so it cuts off after about one to two hours of playing, and going back to the linearity and lack of sidequests, its only good for two playthroughs until more is added. It is, however, a promising indie visual novel. Its's not one of the greats, but it's not bad either.

And again, its currently free, so its something to do for a few hours

reviewText: Pretty good game so far, its a game far from completion at this moment since its still within beta , but the game as is ,is not that bad, it includes an interesting storyline, as well as interesting characters , each with their own personalities , unique back stories , Ryder abilities and their own way of interacting with the other characters within the ship, though i must warn you, while this game has a serious main story line , it plays out alot like a harem anime, with all other main characters being female and in their own way likeing you the only main male protagonist , as well as there are some very mature scenes that occure , not all currentl y have art depicting the situation , while others do with the nude shower scene, as well as the game will in the future have Hentai grade sex scenes, but can be completely avoided ( these scenes are currently not in-game) . Excluding the pervy side this game has, its great , it has pretty good story line, great characters, great backstories for them, overall i think its  great game . Thats all for the story line wise, actual game play wise is a completely differnent story , The moments in the game in which you must fight in battles against pirates or PACT bring you to a command screen in which you will control your main ship the sunrider and all the main characters in their ryders ( with the exception of Ava), how ever the game kinda just drops you in , it explains a little bit of what each attack type does , how ever it barely explains any of the abilities that ryders have , forcing you to experiment all the abilities for each character , which can be very troublesom with the fact that some characters drop into your command in the middle of a battle in which you are outnumbered and/or out gunned , making it hard to use them to their max. The battle scenes can get quite laggy and the coding isnt that strong and miscalculations with hit chances are common , for an example you just used one of your ryders to use a pulse attack which is multiple lazer shots with a lower hit chance than a normal lazer , you then try to use another character that happens to be a marksman and you try to use her kennetic sniper attack, the percentage to hit your opponent might at first dispay a lower chance of 10% or 15% or what ever depending on your range, it will either then auto-correct its self or you might have to deselect and then reselect the attack again for the percentage displayed to correct it selfs , which is important because the percent shown is the actual percent of your attack hiting regardless of what your actually using , which can screw you over if you just rush a shot , but it can also be effective if you glitch the game to make a low accuracy, heavy damage shot have a higher chance of hitting than normal. the Pact or Pirate turns are usually very long since they usually outnumber you by a larg e amount and if they use missles you have to wait for the missle to travel accross the map and hit you before it goes to the next attack making turns very VERY long, but spaming space helps out alot. at an overall gameplay is enjoyable once you either experiment and find out what the absolute ♥♥♥♥ happens when you hit the big red button , or you google this stuff ( which i was unsuccsesfull in doing ) so the acctual gamplay is kind crappy, once you figure things out its like a 6/10 it needs to be inproved on , which sucks alot cause the story line is incredibly interesting and when somthing goes wrong it stirs your emotions up , over all this game is a 7/10 great amazing storyline and character interaction while game play is crap, if your like me youll probably just turn the game play down to the lowest difficulty just to get to the next part of storyline stuff. this is deffinetely a game to watch untill its full release, if you are into just pure story i would go for it right now and see if you enjoy it, if gamplay is your thing i would watch this game for now then, as I've heard its full release will be with in 6 months to  a year .

reviewText:
This game excels as a visual novel, but fails as a strategy game.

The battle portions of the game are clunky. Numbers are so small they're impossible to read. Clicking on an attack icon (on the left side of the screen) sometimes causes units to move to the right, for no apparent reason. Other times, after failing to make an attack due to being out of range, suddenly no units would be able to move. They had enough energy to move, and I was clicking on an allowed space, but the game would be unresponsive. Attacks would still work, as would clicking on other units to switch focus to them, but no units would move. On top of that, every single attack seems to lead to a cutscreen, which thankfully can be skipped through with skip mode, but sometimes dialogue appears during battles. And when there's dialogue, unless you've read it before, you have to manually click through it, which brings you out of skip mode, so the next time you make an attack, there's another cutscreen. It's unbearable. If the battle portions weren't so frustrating to deal with, they'd probably be a lot of fun.

Because of the difficulties I was having with combat, I was hesitant to keep playing. I wasn't sure I was going to like this game. But the story part (which is the majority of the game, thankfully) more than makes up for its awful combat portions. I kept playing, and I didn't regret it. The next thing I knew, it was nearly 2 AM and I was crying.

It's too bad there's a no battles whatsoever" difficulty level

reviewText:
A+ writing makes Sunrider: First Contact/Mask of Arcadius a GREAT visual novel game that chronicles the first two chapters of your journey as the captain of the starship Sunrider.

No dating per se, but your choices do influence reactions from the girls. Decision making is more about your path as a captain--this is interstellar war after all--and you are fighting for the lives of billions of people and the freedom of hundreds of planets.

Characters are well drawn, have unique personalities, and are each likeable. Game play is a solid mix of tactical combat and vehicle leveling; voice acting is outstanding; a good soundtrack and sound effects round it out. Advice: enemies become over-powered as the story unfolds, so save your game and save your command points for later battles.

LoveInSpace creates quality stories that stick with you.
I am very much looking forward to Sunrider: Liberation Day

reviewText: played this game for over 30 hours and absolutely loved it. Besides a few cheesy lines here and there the story is well written and each character feels unique from each other. The combat system is fun dspite a few lags here and there causing misclicks and possibly ruinging the whole turn for you, (however the restart turn function is a great way to combat this problem) had one crash the entire time and was able to fix it simply with a restart of the game. The difficulty can be a bit challenging to those who are playing this type of game for the first time, (I did my first playthrough on VN difficulty and still failed). After my third try however I was able to beat the game on a higher difficulty and had a blast the entire time. I would give this game a strong 7/10, with some small problems fixed it's easily an 8/10.

reviewText:
Alright, you got your Mass Effects, your Gundams, and Your Xcom's.
Now if you were to combine all three(for some insane reason) you would end up with Sunrider:Mask of Arcadius.

In reality, Sunrider is a turn based, hex grid, space combat game mixed with a visual novel. The combat is somewhat unbalaced, but I personaly feel it suits the atmosphere of being the underdog, with you and small sqq\uad of fighters fighting an armada. The first two parts of the game have been released, with the final part set for this year. I've seen some complaints that the whole dating bit is wonky, but I'm only a quarter of the way through. The thing I'd say the most about it  is that it's a great gateway drug into the whole VN genre. as the weaboo ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t is off set by the the tatical combat.

Also it's free, which is a plus.

reviewText:
I honestly do not understand all of the great reviews that this game is getting. After playing for several hours I thought I was finally enjoying the game, but then I looked to my left and saw the four bottles of beer I had downed in half an hour and realized that I was just drunk. That's right, I could only enjoy this game drunk. It's that bad.

The game has two gameplay modes: the visual novel sections through which most of the story is told, and the turn-based strategy battles. Let's address the strategy section first. It is awful. It's not deep nor is it complex. On the default difficulty (Captain) you are at the mercy of a crappy AI. There are missions where it is impossible to guarantee that you will survive the AI's first turn. For example, in one escort mission the AI can easily destroy the unit you are escorting on their first turn; there is nothing you can do to stop this. The only reason you win this mission is if the AI makes crappy decisions and doesn't focus on the escorted ship. And the AI is not scripted to make this bad decision. It will (and did for me) focus down the escorted ship on the first turn several times. Scenarios like this make me feel like I did not defeat a competent opponent, but simply got lucky. The player should never feel like they just got lucky in a strategy game. It's poor design, plain and simple. On top of that, this game suffers from the same problem as XCOM. The random number generator can ruin even the best laid plans. Sure, this is realistic and works if everything else is balanced well. Unfortunately, everything else is not balanced.

Now to the visual novel section. It's also very bad. The characters are 2-dimensional, walking tropes. Nothing about them feels unique or human. You have the (cold)-tsundere, the girl from the countryside with an adowable (read: annoying) accent, the shy girl, the (angry)-tsundere, the Tease, the emotionless quiet girl, the overly loyal service member. It's terrible. Now, nothing is wrong with using tropes, but the tropes should be used to build characters, not define them. Hell, one of the tsundere characters has a line during battle of, I-I'm not doing this because I like you!" Really? Was the writer even trying to make characters beyond simple tropes? I really hope not.

As for the story
date: there was ONE twist that was decent. I won't spoil it. It's predictable
recommended: but at least the foreshadowing is handled in a slightly subtle way. The other major twist
hoursPlayed: at the end of the second chapter is incredibly obvious and I'm not even sure if it should count as a twist. Overall
voteText: the story is very bland. The entire first chapter consists of collecting your harem

votesHelpful: which is mediocre due to predictable twists and bland characters.\n\nLet's get to the main reason you play visual novels (no
votesTotal: not the for the H-scenes
votesFunny: I'll get to that): Choices! Oh
commentsCount: this game is full of choices! Wonderful choices! That mean nothing. Literally nothing. There is only one choice in the entire game that changes anything beyond the scene in which that choice is made. What's the point? Why have a choice mechanic is all but one choice won't matter. Maybe they matter in the third chapter
column16: but I don't care. Choices should have consequences that ripple out throughout the plot. They shouldn't just magically make the ending change without changing how that ending is arrived at.\n\nAbout that H-Scene (yes

reviewText:
So far what I consider this a pretty alright VN.

The story is pretty interesting, as the way the game gives you a feeling of control you have over how the story goes. You can make a choice by morals or by your feelings of revenge.

Although it is in beta, I do not recommend this yet, until proper features get into the game.
Being able to disable voice by character is a common option for VNs, being able to save just about anywhere and to also load just about anywhere is a must. A battle restart button is in need as I accidentily will  misclick an action and as a result absolutely ♥♥♥♥s over the whole battle for me.
I would also like to be able to turn off battle cut scenes. They are annoying when you get into large battles and might be lagging the game itself. Various notes and tips need to be put in to explain certain ablities (I still have no idea how stealth works since it doesn't stop enemies from attacking the character.)
Please also restrict the amount of missles the enemy has, the battles are insanly hard when going against multiple enemies that carry missles, since they will continue to bombard all my units will infinate missles, while I am only able to carry 1/2 on only a few of mine.

The voice acting is average-subpar for English (not that suprising). The lines are quite repetitive as they play every time you select, attack, move, or get attacked. It's also filled with internet memes, which really should never be seen as a positive thing as it brings down the quality of the story. There is also a desprate need for more male pilots, since having a cast of female = good guys, male = bad guys gives me a bad taste in my mouth- the commander needs some bros too you know.

Overall it's a pretty alright game, but needs more polishing- which really shouldn't be happening after a VN gets released.

reviewText:
Boy I hate to be the downer review on a free game, but...

Personally I found this game not to be worth my time, and I typically finish every game I own, even if I got it for free/Its not very good. I got to near the end (I believe), but if you're sitting and hoping this is the last encounter as you try it for the third time in aggrivation...its really not worth finishing. I'll go over the three main points I found lacking.

VISUAL NOVEL: As a visual novel, it is -really- lacking. The characters are rather boring, and the choices you make during the story very clearly do not affect what is going on...later on there are a few choices the game doesn't even acknowledge, and just keeps going. I understand branching paths in a strategy game is rather difficult, especially for a free project, but I have seen it done well. If nothing else, at least give the illusion your choices matter, or don't give them at all.

STORY: As with the above, the story is very bland, and you can drive holes through some of the pieces of plot. I didn't expect Mass Effect or the like, but the characters really drag things down, the whole thing just starts to mesh together, and at the end I was skipping through the flashbacks with annoyance, as they really didn't add anything to the plot other than what felt like an entirely pointless sex scene and to give a reason why we should care about generic dead sister that has not been mentioned until now.

GAMEPLAY: Urg. The sad thing is, the strategy part of the game is very well balanced, with different weapons having different uses. The problem is, the game is balanced, but the fights are not. If you're going to send the player up against 5-1 odds or more, they need to have a significant advantage on their side. You don't. You will often lose units in the first turn of a fight just due to sheer overwhelming firepower. Your units are in general more powerful than similar enemy units, but only in options. Your units are very set in a certain role, and tend to get easily knocked out of it. The sniper unit that can one shot almost everything? Completely useless once the enemy starts getting units that decrease your energy, thus letting her do nothing the entire fight. The buffer unit who can heal or disable units? The same. The other buffer unit? Can't even do that, just a vague 'aim decrease' or damage buff, neither of which makes an appreciable difference. The first mech unit you get in the game? Her major attacks are lasers, which tend to be useless when enemies all start having shields, missiles which go the same for flak, leaving her doing about nothing for most of the game. I hate playing on anything lower than normal, but the first escort mission forced me to do so as you are quickly overwhelmed with no recourse or alternate strategy other than 'try again and get lucky' and even at a lower difficulty the later missions got overwhelmingly onesided, without the abusive strategy of 'warp and major cannon death'.

Yes it is free, and its not completely worthless, but it is -very- aggrivating, and there are much better games to spend your time on, even if you have to spend a little for them.

reviewText:
Well, the story is weak and uninspired, the visuals are decent but not amazing, and while I'm impressed with the Ren'Py engine once again, that really can't reflect back on this game. At the end of the day, the thing that really made me sit up and take notice was the music. I couldn't find a list in the credits, so I have to assume that it's all compiled by the sound engineer until I find out otherwise. The music is suitably epic, it's tasteful electronica with a little bit of metal thrown in, and it really did wonders for the rest of the game.

I also have to say that even though over 75% of the voice actors were the irritating 'japanese space chibi' characters that grind on my nerves, the voice actor for Commander Ava was easy to listen to, and a few of her one-off lines were actually very emotional.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend this game, because it's a japanese space chibi harem game, without a compelling premise (PLAY HOMEWORLD INSTEAD, IT'S BETTER) or interesting, multidimensional characters. Still, the gameplay was surprisingly smooth and enjoyable, and I lost almost 3 hours to it. I'm definitely going to keep an eye on this studio, because there's a lot of promise here.

reviewText: The beta needs work. The game tends to slow down alot, start lagging. I was looking at my cpu usage and this game is cpu intensive. It didnt take any power from the GC, which is the strong point in my PC. I tried playing this game on easy mode, thinking I would have a breeze playing it and enjoying what appeared to be a neat storyline, however, what happened was not the case. All the combat that had taken up to a certain point was very easy, hoever, *SPOILER ALERT* when I have to escort a civilian ship from one side of the grid to the other and the eny does nothing but keep respawing, respawning 3-4 ships at a time AND ganging up on my ryders so I was left with only the firepower the sunrider can muster? It was like I was playing against a player. I tried changing strategies, changing tactics, I went back and redid some of the specs I bought on the ship, but alas, to no avail. Either my ryders are ganged up and shot to hell, so theres no CHANCE I have the firepower I need, or the civilian ship gets ganged up on, either way, I cannot complete the mission at all. Im sure if i spent 4-5 hours, grinding it out, looking for a way to get it done, I could do it. But im on EASY mode! EASY! I shouldnt have to do that. I believe this game is shaping up to be an awesome VN, however, its easy to see why it's still in beta. CPU optimization need to be taken care of, so there's no chance of accidentally misclicking (which happened alot) because of lag, and some level balancing needs to take place.

reviewText: The concept is solid, and apparently theres a visual novel within this game, somewhere. I wouldn't know, as the RNG got me killed on multiple occassions. Usually I don't mind when theres an 80% chance to hit and I miss, cause at least the odds are understandble. Multiple misses at 97%, however, seems broken. The story builds up our character to be the galaxy's hope with the best ship in the fleet. Be that as it may, 1000 hits at 1 damage still does 1000 damage, and the RNG makes us miss more often than not, without giving us the same curtosy for the enemy units. There is a mission early on where we have three units and are expected to last against no less than 10 units, which are far tankier than the average mook. For a free beta, its got a good concept. I just hope by the time its fully released, the RNG will make more sense.

reviewText:
Really disappointed with this one. I don't play a lot of them, but I'm a big fan of tactics games like Advance Wars and Fire Emblem. I obviously wasn't expecting such perfectly polished and balanced gameplay from a free visual novel but man... even my low expectations weren't met. The combat in the game is slow, frustrating and boring. Just look at the demo video on the store page. A single round of one (1) player turn and one (1) A.I. Enemy turn is 4 minutes. FOUR MINUTES! It's not four tatical minutes, four minutes of asking 'what's my next move...?', it's four minutes of animations! of boring, samey shooty laser animations. Since every battle happens in space the developers haven't created terrain elements so you fight on an open field, because fighting takes place on an open field the devs found it appropriate to make movement and attacking draw on the same action resource energy. Attacks don't have a fixed range like in a Fire Emblem game, but longer distances effect accuracy. So when, exactly, is it optimal for me to waste a third of a unit's energy to decrease its chance of being hit by 15%? Battles turn into stagnant ships firing lasers at each other turn after turn, missing then doing minimal damage then missing. The appeal of space battles is totally free movement and this game seems to miss this point all together.

Why do I have to click to advance the screen after an attack completes? Why would a still image of ship stay on my screen when nothing is happening? Why doesn't this advance automatically? Why does the game let you end a turn without any warning while you still have energy left? This might not happen a lot, but since your end turn button it right next to all your attack and ability buttons, it will happen a few times at least. Also, mousing over certain corners of your action buttons, including the end turn button, causes the screen to scroll. You can't adjust the camera during attack 'animation' sequences and the camera doesn't auto focus on battle action so if you've accidentally scrolled away from the tiny part of the map where units actually are, get ready to have a fun enemy turn trying to get the camera centred! Alternatively, you could just mash left click until it's your turn again. You won't miss much.

As for the visual novel aspect of the game, I'm unimpressed. If a bunch of anime girls in tight clothing explaining the plot is what you look for in a game, more power to you. When you start with one of the most generic openings and hero motivations (a shady empire destroyed my home) and deliver it in the most predictable way imaginable (what a nice peaceful planet i hope nothing happens to it; alderan much, anybody? hyuk) its hard for me to get invested. When the dialogue isn't gripping because its riddled with anime clichés it's hard for me to get invested. When the game introduces a non-visual novel game mode that drags down the whole experience, I delete local content and move on.
voteText: 1 of 10 people (10%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius is an indie visual novel with a catch. Depending on
the choice you make at the start of the game, you will play anything ranging
from a good visual novel to a terrible turn-based spaceship battle game.  I had
pleasure to try both the former (visual novel difficulty setting) and the
latter (hard difficulty setting). This review is, therefore, split into two
separate sections covering both variations of the game separately.

First of all, I probably would not even consider playing this game if it was
not free, unless I got a strong recommendation from a friend, or the game came
as a part of a bundle; this game being free will only cost you about 1GiB of
bandwidth to play and you should definitely check it out.

Also, thanks to the technology the game is created with (RenPy) this game is
supported across three major operating systems. Sunrider deserves a big plus
just for diversifying Linux gaming ecosystem.

The great side: visual novel mode
As long as visual novels are concerned there’s three things they have going for
them: story, art and sound, and the game does fine at most of them.

Story

This game has a traditional science fiction setting – in a far future the
humanity has already inhabited most of the galaxy, they have huge spaceships,
warping devices and laser weapons, and, obviously there’s evil guys who try to
take over the same galaxy. The writing is very approachable and easy to follow,
but repetitive, cliché at times. Sunrider being a visual novel, ability to make
some “important” story-altering decisions as the story progresses would be
expected; capability to make the decisions is presented, but they appear to
have no substantial effect to the story at all: throw a girl into a confinement
chamber and you will still find her in your virtual harem sometime soon anyway.

Art

The story is wrapped into beautiful japanimation-style art, as common to most
of the visual novels. It is clear that much attention was dedicated to it and I
hereby declare art to be the best thing about Sunrider.

Sound

Unlike the art, the music is in a much worse shape. While the selection of
tracks is quite likeable, they have a severe deficiency that should not have
been overlooked for beta – the tracks lack any form of loudness normalisation.
You will find yourself reaching for volume control to save your ears when a
louder than usually track starts casually ♥♥♥♥♥♥ them.

On the positive side, the characters are voiced! I’m making the Asaga’s “I’m
firing my lasers” my alarm right now. A big +1 here.

The bad side: combat mode
Now, if you happen to make a mistake and pick any difficulty harder than the
“visual novel”, you will find yourself battling 8-bit sprites better part of
the game instead of indulging in textual pleasures with your virtual harem
and, occasionally, a dude or two. This does not sound like a problem until you
realize there’s only a few types of units available to fight against and they
are all powered by a pretty stupid, suicidal AI (more likely, just a few hard
coded patterns) making the combat mode a lackluster.

Sound

The playlist in combat mode seems to differ somewhat from the one used for the
visual novel mode. Regardless, music here suffers from the same issues
mentioned in the visual novel part of the review. Moreover, all this is made
worse by the playback of the tracks: they are stopped after each turn and
another randomly selected track is started from the beginning when next turn
comes around. This results in a feeling of discontinuity and, alas, makes it
hard to appreciate the possibly fine music in its full form.

Misc
Bugs

While I realise this is a beta version, it is still quite easy to encounter a
crasher or two and get thrown back into the main menu losing all your progress
past the last save. Other bugs I found (where’s the “report a bug” button?)
qualify for beta-grade and mostly consist of graphical issues such as
miscalculated text baselines in research fund allocation screen.

---

In conclusion, while I’d like to rate this game as two separate games, Steam
only has a single binary switch. Therefore, unless I rate visual novel part
>8/10, the average score turns out to be less than ½, hence the “thumbs-down”.

reviewText: I initially loved everything about the concept of this game. Interactive novel? Sure. Sci-Fi setting? Absolutely. Turn-based tactical combat system with upgrades? It's like a dream come true. Great in theory, but poorly executed.\n\nI slammed face first in a massive difficulty spike early in the game. Playing on normal, I went from clearing the maps with no challenge to facing non-stop failures. I tried everything I could think of, and I faced a mission so terribly unbalanced that it has all the hallmarks of being unbeatable. Reading through the forums, this is an issue that's been known since at least August and still hasn't been resolved. I have lost all interest in trying to progress past this and seeing the rest of the game, or of anything else from the developers. If they can't get the balance right on something right at the start, where does that leave me thinking about anything else they do? If you aren't going to try and make it a fun experience, why bother having it there at all?

reviewText:
A game with potential, which it unfortunately wastes. If I had to sum up the game in a word: Bland.

Everything about this game is generic or disappointing. Let me run through a quick list:
-Characters are standard sci-fi anime archetypes, done completely straight. They feel like cardboard cutouts, not characters.

-Character art is decent, but plain and the poses are quite stiff. The skintight latex space suits aren't anything thrilling, either.

-Stilted, unnatural dialog and forced exposition. This isn't helped by how the ship apparently only has two people on it early on, who get stuck expositting between each other in really forced ways. Especially jarring was the supposed terror of seeing an enemy's super weapon reading like B-movie acting.

-Utterly forgettable ship and robot designs. Nothing you probably haven't seen a dozen times before.

-A plot that comes off as painfully forced and cliched. Enemy fleet manages to sneak up to your homeworld despite the supposed existance of an allied fleet. Apparently the only ship in the area is yours, which is still in dry dock without having finished its test run. The only reason your ship even survives is because the enemies are so incompetent that they shoot the dry dock instead of the immobile ship. Then you fly off to meet the fleet, which is immediately decimated by the aforementioned super weapon, which proceeds to nuke a city we are supposedly to care about, despite never having seen it. Oh, and how the characters instantly know there have been a million casualties despite the very next line indicating that you've lost all contact with civilian and military command. All to set up the same 'one ship again an entire enemy empire' plot that, again, you've probably seen a dozen times before.

That's just the first mission, mind. The second mission goes the unfortunate route of throwing not only a little girl pirate (who is both in command and has a hair trigger for being called little, because that's totally character depth and not just another tired trope!) at you, who will apparently blow multiple holes into your hull in one shot, despite said shot doing a piddly amount of damage. All to force a cutscene where some girl shows up to bail you out from out of nowhere. Apparently I'm supposed to be impressed by the rescue from enemies I could probably obliterate on my own?

And it is at this point I shut down the game and started writing this review, because of the final nail in this game's coffin. You see, as much as I like a solid plot and interesting characters (and trope heavy games can still be interesting if handled well), I can tolerate a dull plot if the gameplay is fun enough.

-The gameplay is not fun. If some of the problems were shored up, it could be above average. But as it stands, gameplay is plodding, combat is bland, there's constant animation lag due to system inefficiencies and the game doesn't offer anything I couldn't find in other games.

With all that, I can't even find it in me to be angry at anything in this game. It's just so bland and boring that I had to get a cup of coffee just to stave off my apathy long enough to write this review. That isn't a joke.

I am left wondering why anyone thought cobbling together a combat system for ren'py of all things was a good idea, though. It's a sytem designed for visual novels, where there will be a background and four character sprites/images on screen at most and all gameplay is menu based. It's good at what it's designed for, but as you can see, trying to force it to do something it wasn't designed for leaves it a sluggish mess.

But with that being said, I think I'll keep the game installed for a while. As I said in the beginning: It has potential. It's just that all that potential is sadly untapped right now. Maybe after a couple months of fixing the slow combat and editing the writing a bit, I'll come back and love the game. It would be unexpected, but certainly a pleasant surprise. So here's hoping, I suppose.

reviewText:
This is a solid sRPG. What that means is that my luck gives my 95% chance to hits a 0% chance, and the enemy has a better chance of missing your mom than my fleet. I gave up after the fifth or sixth battle proved too difficult to complete on normal (my 5 ships were taking well over 2000 points of damage in the first volley, I could maybe dish out 1200 points of damage and take out 1 significant damage source). I can't confirm whether you can upgrade ryders or not, as it was impossible for me to get to a point where I had an option of upgrading more than my primary ship.

I don't find games that require you to savescum in order to barely survive the fights a well-balanced game, so I can't recommend it.

That said: if RNGesus actually likes you, and you enjoy sRPGs, this game should scratch that itch, and the price can't be beat! I should point out the music is actually quite decent, and if you like Voiceovers and crisply drawn mecha, they have those, too.

reviewText:
This game has SO MUCH going for it that it almost hurts telling people NOT to play it.

First, the Pro's. The story line is Really good, the characters are funny and original (internet puns to the side XD) and their actually Believable. They never felt like they were closet characters or puppets, they actually felt believable. The combat (AT FIRST!) was interesting and innovative, it handled differently, but in a good way.

Cons

The game is IMPOSSIBLE to beat. Period. There's a point later on in the game (I'll not say whats going on for spoiler's sake) But the enemy fires rockets at you. The AI is programmed to SPAM missles and rockets, missles do ok damage, rockets do a TON. After being ♥♥♥♥♥ (I mean, as in my main battleship died on round TWO because those ♥♥♥♥ers fired ALL their rockets and missles and killed me instantly) about 6 times, and the other four my Ryders (pilotable mechs) were destroyed first, leaving the Sunrider (your main battleship) the sole focus, making the mission completely impossible. I really don't see how your supposed to be able to fight this, and if this fight is an indication of battles to come. I want NOTHING to do with this game. The unfairness of the combat, and how the AI can completely smoke you like that ruins all the pro's.

I LOVE RTS games. I love RPG games....Again, this game has SO MUCH POTENTIAL....if they would JUST remove missles and rockets from the AI ships.

reviewText:
IF youre absolutely starving for both games and cash then I'd recommend playing through this however I couldnt recommend this to anyone with more options available to them. To start with the prose is a bit poor and there were some turns of phrase so odd they forced me to look it up to confirm that it was, in fact, written by americans. The characters are cliches played entirely straight which fits in well with the developers obstinate adherence to the visual novel genre and its painful idosyncrasies. The overarching storyline is somewhat blatantly that of the Star Wars prequels and with the equal lack of orginal or empathizable characters it seems the only creative thought involved was the addition of turn based combat.

The turn based combat in question is much the same as the VN section except that most of its user interface issues are solely its own rather than attributes of the genre. The limited number of your units ,especially in the early stages of the game, leads to relatively short periods of you actually doing anything followed by incredibly long periods of enemies incredibly poorly animated cutscene attacks. The tactics themselves are rather basic though the general lack of explantion of various statistics and the small size of text in what few tooltips exist serves to rather effectively disguise that fact.

Overall the game isn't terrible but your time would be better spent on something with a bit more charm.

reviewText:
It's free, so go ahead and give it a try.
It's story is decent, and I wish I got through it.
The combat is quite ♥♥♥♥ poor. I really wish these types of games just let you skip the tedious combat and read the story...guess I'll just have to go some other place to read the story.
No tooltips of any description. Want to activate stealth? What does it do? You have no god damned idea, so try it...it gives +100% stealth...what does stealth do? Everything can and will still attack it.
Not to mention, you will miss EVERY 90% shot you take, and enemies will hit with each of their 10% shots.
There's also the fact that there is no autosave, so if you get stuck in an unwinnable battle, you are actually stuck unless you saved before. I could forgive it, if it had actually said there was no autosave.
There are also performance problems, where it lags when doing to whole battle animation thing. As someone who custom built their computer to run top end games and edit music videos, I find this quite unacceptable, especially from a visual novel-esque game.
This is solved if you used the skip option before entering combat...don't know how to use it during combat...so kinda annoying there.

reviewText:
Relatively easy play, until you get to the wedding crash mission. Then it becomes impossible. Played several hours on the same level, gave up on the game at that point.

Otherwise, it's a fun game. Nice visual novel settings. A bit risque, but that's what we're all in here for, anyway. A big ol' harem full of busty mech pilots. Who needs Eva when you have this masterpiece?

Mechanics-wise, aside from the aforementioned impossible level, things go pretty well. The challengingness (challengingness?) of the game is just about right. You can't exactly breeze through it, but it's still playable (again, until that impossible level).

Overall, I'd give it a 7/10. Would've given 8.5/10, but the impossible level spoiled the whole game for me. Still feel bad about not finishing it, but I just can't do it… Online gameplay vids don't help either.

reviewText:
It's GREAT for a free game (IT DIDN'T TRY TO SELL ME ANYTHING!)

Strengths:
- The music is very nice.
- The graphics are...the selling point...most likely...yeah...

Why didn't I recommend it? It attempts to be both a graphical novel and a tactical space game, and neither are done well enough for me to enjoy the game more than about 10 minutes.

Weaknesses with the combat aspect:
- Choppy UI and slow pace
- Nothing special about the combat
(I spent more time writing this review than I did playing the game, so ... I could be wrong.)

Weaknesses with the novel aspect:
- The opening of the game feels a little too familiar: your ship's built, still needs polish but it's pretty much good to go, and it's being attacked! Fight!!! Oh my gosh! Mega ship! Run and we will return to avenge the homeworld!!!
- The text when people talk is really small, my eyes hurt trying to read it.
- People who I don't know at the beginning of the game are talking a lot and I'm not feeling them.
- [/me looks at data files in the steam folder...] Where are the men? I think that even if I was a boy with raging hormones in junior high just wanting to look at hot chicks on space ships, I'd still like to have someone I could relate to.
- There's someone at the beginning whose name is Shields (there are no graphics for any males, btw), I thought I was talking to the Shields system or something, I'm not sure. Maybe someone was a fan of Brooke Shields and they thought it could be like a first name? I feel like if I keep playing I will run into all sorts of what I guess are translation weirdness and that makes me feel uncomfortable.

reviewText:
First of all, why hasn't this been done before, such a simple game, free, and personally, I would pay $25 for it, if not more.

Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius, is a turn-based strategy game, with anime-style graphics set in a distant future, humanity reigns supreme over the entire galaxy (and possibly beyond) two major factions are at each others' throats, but not at war (yet), The Solar Alliance, led by Admiral Grey, the Alliance controls most of the inner colonies, but like any other civilisation, there is much discontent in the civillian masses of the Neutral Rim, where pirates, bandits and marauderers fight with each other, and raid ships, y'know piratey stuff. On a world, beyond the Alliance's reach, a slave boy has grown up, and grown tired of the pirates, slavers and other criminal riff-raff, and forms PACT, an anti-alliance orginisation, hell-bent on taking control of the galaxy so they can help the common man. PACT sounds like a good faction when you look at the job description, but by action, it is clear they are no friend of anyone, not realising, or ignoring their inner-dictator, PACT attacks the neutral world Cera, home to captain Kayto Sheilds, and first officer Ava, who have been entrusted with the hyper-advanced warship, Sunrider.

Together with a baker, a wannabe hero, a merc, a girl from another time, a discredited medical officer and a black ops agent (which you don't exactly start with any of them with you. The game has boss fights" where only two of them have unique units

reviewText:
Short version

Pros:
1. Good story and characters (with one possible exception).
2. Decent turn-based combat.
3. Very funny moments.

Cons:
1. A bit immature at times.
2. Combat gets frustrating and un-fun near the end of the game.
3. I'm suspiciously surrounded by attractive young women.

Long version:

Let me start out by saying that I have not seen enough anime to recognize tropes. Because to me these characters appeared to be fully fleshed out and enjoyable individuals. Regardless of what the others say I found them to be likable and believable (with the exception of Claude who's only personality trait is that she's hopelessly infatuated with you). They have there own problems and strengths that they bring to the gameplay. Everyone of them is a capable warrior who contributes a great deal to the combat when used properly.
The story itself starts out pretty basic. Take revenge against the jerk who destroyed everything you hold dear. the game also gets amazingly deep at the same time. They allow the world that they have created to mirror our own to a large degree. Anyone with a passing understanding of history will notice that the main villains are Space Communists and that the urban warfare story arch is remniscent of our fights in the Middle East. In fact, the game takes a long, hard look at the horrors of war when you can't tell friend from foe and the consequences thereof. It really challenged me to reconsider how war should be conducted. It should be noted that it didn't change my mind but it forced me to accept that such conditions are simply horrible.
Back to the characters. They all have a certain charm about them. There's not a one that I wish was not there. Even Claude (shallow as she is) brings a certain entertainment value with her. Most have a tragic backstory that elicited an emotional response from me (though it could be that I'm a sucker for a pretty face).
The combat seems hit-or-miss to me. On one hand it has several ways of doing damage. Each method has it use and optimal situation, but it always seemed better to get into a situation where one heavier damage types could be used. I always ended up grouping my units together for prtection and going from there. Flanking is not an option. Ever. It can also be rather frustrating later as hundreds of missiles get thrown at you until one or two of your units are down by the second round. Eventually I lowered the difficulty until I could just proceed with the story. This is largely because the story was by far the strongest element of the game.
Then there's the fanservice." I know that it's my fault for not looking into the game enough (ooooh free stuff)
date: but  I rather wish it wasn't there. I came to love the characters when they were fully dressed
recommended: I will continue to love them even if they remain so. There is really no need for such gimmicks. Especially since the writers have proven that they can craft a beautiful galaxy and narrative without such foolishness. Basically

I absolutely recommend this.

As I played this game, I could not help but become immersed - both the combat and the story are interesting. It reminds me of a mix between best elements of the Mass Effect series, Battlestar Galactica, and Tenchi Muyo GXP. If you are a fan of any of the genres I just mentioned, you will certainly enjoy this. For something that's free to play, I'm in disbelief of how much I enjoyed it. It's absolutely worth the 14 - 15 hours of time.

10/10, will buy sequels; will replay.

- There's someone at the beginning whose name is Shields (there are no graphics for any males, btw), I thought I was talking to the Shields system or something, I'm not sure. Maybe someone was a fan of Brooke Shields and they thought it could be like a first name? I feel like if I keep playing I will run into all sorts of what I guess are translation weirdness and that makes me feel uncomfortable.

reviewText:
There are not many Science fiction Mech games out there.

I played this game on my Linux computer for about 10 hours and its fun.
Every character has it's own personality and way they do things. That causes funny and arkward situations on the spaceship. Music is good, it's suits the game very well. The drawings are nice. The mechs look good and have several small animations. Due to money constrains they could not add more, cause it has been funded by Kickstarter. Althought low budget the game does not feel cheap, but nice en enjoyable to play. The battles require some tactics, it's not just do something and you will win. The mechs and ship can be upgraded with the spoils of war, the money you gain from destroying enemies. During the conversations and actions between enemies and friends you can choose what to say.

One remark: It would have been great if they chose to implement the basegame as 12 years old and the 18+ as an upgrade. There is an uncensor option somewhere on their website....

Overall a good game. Thanks to Kickstarter, it has become totally free on Steam!
Thank you people who saw this game on Kickstarter and payed for it!

reviewText:
Okay, this is going to be interesting.

Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius

So first of all, what is it? Okay, take mass effect, mash it with your favorite visual novel, then bake it with some really fun gameplay. And then you have this thing.

Lets start with the actual game elements- the tactical combat. While it might have not been the most complex system out of this genre, I found it to be interesting enough to be both fun and challanging. The ability to upgrade your individual units was a very nice touch. Gameplay was really well done, very satisfied.

Now lets move on to the characters/art design. I have to say I really enjoyed the whole artstyle of this game, from the mechs (Ryders) you command, to your crewmembers, it was all very well made. The characters themselves prove to be the best part about this game, each with their own unique personality, if a bit cliche at times.

Okay, here's the big part. The story.
Where do I even begin?
For the most part, it reminds me a lot of mass effect, it has a very similar setting, along with certain other things about the game. For the most part it's sort of cliche, not much done here that hasn't been done before.
And then there's the visual novel" part.
For the first three quarters of the game I was enjoying everything
date: till about near the end where the main character randomly has a mental breakdown before confessing his love to TWO girls I didn't even care much about to begin with. You're given no choice as to who you want to be with in the story
recommended: an aspect which I found extremely disappointing for such an otherwise great game. You are given decisions
hoursPlayed: which do affect the game
voteText: just not quite in the way I'm satisfied with.\n\nOverall
helpfulPercent: the game is really fun
votesHelpful: the gameplay is solid
votesTotal: the characters are great
votesFunny: the overall story is pretty good
commentsCount: but I was disappointed in the "visual novel" aspect of the game.\n\nIt is however
column16: free
column17: and gave me about 24 hours of campaign time
column18: so I definately recommend playing this to anyone slightly interested in visual novels
column19: science fiction
column20: or mass effect.\n\n***8/10***"

reviewText:
Absolutely would recommend this game.

I was always a big fan of the Disgaea games.  They intermixed focused tactical battles with an interesting and entertaining story.  I think this achieves the same.  It was a very pleasureable and challenging playthrough.

I was very fond of the leveling system with one criticism.  You'll find yourself leveling 'just enough' to get a particular combo you are interested in being able to use.  So you'll experience sudden jumps with specific characters suddenly being able to do their super move twice and the like.  However, this almost exactly suits the planned tactical elements of the game and is likely legit.  Level that character to a good cut off and then focus down another.

Bottom line, great game.  It's got great gameplay combined with a cool story.  The troporific harem is obviously oriented towards a hetero male (and well done!), but if you're missing one or both of those attributes I think you'll have a great play through and some laughs along with it.

reviewText: Well, first i want to say, this game is not really full visual novel which you only read and given option for a branch route. This game offer some challenging gameplay and a nice story. The other players who want some challenging game can play it with higher difficulty (there's even a difficulty who isn't tested by the developer. and i could say it's will be almost impossible to win).  All and all, this game is good and you should really played it

reviewText:
so i've just played this game for little more than an hour, but I have to say this title is pretty cool.
as far as I can see, the main character has a funny, ballsy personality and he doesn't whine too much.
the soundtrack is impressive! not bad for a free game...

the battle system is allright for now, there is a nice variety of weapons and special abilities like augmenting your stats or shutting down enemy's ships.

The fact that you can buy weapons from a galactic mining corporation and that you have a smart ♥♥♥ blue haired girl that builds starship's parts in her sleep just skyrockets the value of this game for me.

Now I have to say the art's style is nothing to be hyped about, it's barely 6/10. the mecha design is rather crude and cliche, but I guess it gets the job done.

the only main issue is the massive lag you get during battle animations, that's really annoying.
Also, I know I haven't played too much, but it feel like the choices I make are just effecting the dating sim side of the game; I might be completely wrong on this, so don't take it for granted.

in the end I think I can close an eye on the crudeness of the arts and the lag problems since the game its free, but I would definitely put some money on it if the devs decide to upgrade the overall quality of this title, there potential...

reviewText:
I played the first 2 (of 3) of the releases of this game.  (The 3rd has not been released, yet.)  This review will reflect my experience with the story as it has progressed thus far.  This game is composed of a Story (i.e. Visual Novel), and a series of many tactical Combat Sequences.  I will rate them individually.

Overall, I give this game a 2 out of 5 Stars.  That translated to a mild Thumbs Down, with some specific caveats.
* Story: 4/5
* Combat: 1/5

This game is a Free to Play (F2P) game, so I have no issues in terms of value vs. price.  However, I did notice many small issues in the dialogue where the phrasing didn't quite match the context.  I'm not sure if this is due to a translation issue, or whether it is consistant with some international style of anime I'm unaware of.  Either way, I found it mentally jarring and annoying. reviewText:
Regardless of what I tell you below, I recommend that you TRY playing this game. Theres a million good reviews and I might be the only person having maddening problems with this game so chances are, you'll enjoy it.  However, not an hour into the game I began to feel like this game might just be unplayable without tearing my hair out from annoyance. These are the problems I have been dealing with..

This game seems to have mostly good reviews and I'm not surprised. I am really enjoying the story so far and the gameplay is creative and fun in concept. OH and I LOVE the music in this game. ...But I am frustrated with my game being slow. There aren't really and graphics options and there really don't need to be. I don't have a custom built gamer-tank of a computer, but I doubt this game is meant to be demanding..

I don't know if I'm alone in this, but transitioning between shots in the battle scenes is hell. After whatever animation has occurred, I find myself constantly wondering if the game is waiting for me to click before it transitions (I'm still not sure). This wouldn't be so terrible if there wasn't a short cutscene initiated by each attack (this early in the game I'm using at least 5 attacks in the round. on top of that, you are often facing many enemies, which means many, many choppy cutscenes).

The screenshots of this game show cool and unique icons representing each unit. I am not seeing that at all. I see the hexagons and numbers representing unit health, move distance, etc. In addition it takes at least five seconds after clicking a unit for its stats or options to pop up. Not to mention the occasional (Program Not Responding) issue upon selecting units.

Overall, I think this game is great in story and gameplay, but the slow interface has left me utterly exhausted and feeling like the extra three hours I expected to stay up playing this wouldn't get me very far at all. I'm just going to go to bed..

reviewText:
This is one of my favourite games of the genre. Its has all the known clichés as is expected by these games, but they are not overdone. The art is great, and game play difficulty can be altered any time.
I love it how you can focus on the battle phase during the story bits that way (by altering the difficulty I mean).

If you are a fan of visual novels, teh replayability is great. Not only if you want to see all the storylines and/or bragging rights but also to replay the battle phases like a turn based strategy game.

reviewText: Sunrider: Mask of Arcadius is one of Steam's best hidden gems.  I will start off by saying this--I hate anime.  Yet, somehow, I am in love with this game.  It is a glorified visual novel that gives you choices in dialogue for taste, although they don't exactly change much (or anything) in the storyline.  Beyond the storyline, which is very impressive, is the combat phase, which I believe is easily the best component of the game--even including the hot women, boobs, and great soundtrack.\n\nTo make a long story short, without spoilers, you play as Kayto Shields, the captain of the Sunrider, and you are thrown into the middle of an intergalactic war, and are forced to play a vital role, unveiling more and more of the story down the road.  The Sunrider has an array of militaristic power on its vessel, ALL of which are upgradable to what seems like an infinite limit, given the resources.  Throughout the story, you will meet formidable foes and loyal allies, who will join your cause with their ryders"
hoursPlayed: and vastly different from one another.\n\nThe combat is utterly fantastic
voteText: especially if you are a fan of turn-based tactical combat.  You control your Sunrider and the rest of your fleet on a hexagonal grid

reviewText:
When I first saw Sunrider, knowing nothing about it, I expected it to be another mediocre amateur visual novel. Picked it up because I saw some nice reviews. The fact it was free was the deciding factor. I was still skeptical about the game in the first hour of so of gameplay, but at that point, it had already surpassed my low expectations with pretty good artwork and a surprisingly awesome soundtrack, so I pressed on. I'm glad I did.

Before I say anything more, I haven't completed the game yet. As I write this I am 16ish hours into the game and have no idea how much longer I have until it ends. Was itching to write something about this game, so consider this a mere first impression.

I'll start with the storyline. Generally speaking, it's your typical sci-fi-themed bad guys want to take over the galaxy" plot. Nothing revolutionary
date: but it's something anyone can get behind. Not to say that it's too bland-- one event in particular substituted otherwise obligatory deus-ex machina for an interesting character development
recommended: so there's more to it than initially meets the eye.\n\nNext up
hoursPlayed: characters. Like the plotline
voteText: the characters never stray too far from their respecting tropes. Any fan of anime
helpfulPercent: manga or other VNs will immediately notice this. You are given your standard-issue sassy girl
votesHelpful: shy girl
votesTotal: ditzy girl
votesFunny: tsundere
commentsCount: kuudere
column16: etc etc characters to work with. Most people I talk to either love or hate that sort of thing. Some
column17: like me
column18: will find them endearing
column19:
others may feel apathetic. You decide.
The main bad guy (thus far) is the malicious masked villain with a penchant for evil laughter. I'm hoping that more will be done with him later on to make him seem less silly.

As for gameplay
column20: Mask of Arcadius features a turn-based strategy element for its battles that can be summarised in one word: CRUEL. I am playing on the default difficulty setting as I usually do for my first playthroughs of games; in this case
column21: the 'Captain' difficulty. I fancy myself a pretty good tactician
column22: especially when it comes to turn-based strategy
column23: but I am stuck on one mission right now that I am semi-convinced is impossible [at this difficulty] without spending your upgrades and command points flawlessly up to that point. The difficulty levels' descriptions give you fair warning and are changeable in game
column24: but this will be the first time that I have to undergo the moral seppuku of lowering a game difficulty below default. It got to a point where my squishier units were being picked off by missiles before my 2nd turn. Even when they miraculously survive
column25: it isn't long before a horde of missile-spewing reinforcements arrive as the final nail in the coffin. Seriously
column26: I haven't died this many times since my first playthrough of Dark Souls.\nThe combat system might benefit from a bit more tweaking while it's in beta
column27: but the gameplay is still very fun and incredibly satisfying to finally win against the always unfavourable odds the game will throw at your from the very beginning. If for nothing else
column28: you should play the game on this merit."
